story:
"Mural in a Day Sonora" means bringing Community together to create a lasting Public Art Mural outdoors that epresses our vibrant cultural life. Imagine...even more.

We are the "Mural in a Day Sonora" Committee. Sarah Rogers Nesper, Laurie Lehmann, B.Z. Smith, Sally Dunn, Robin Phillips, Katie Dunn and Linda Emerson. We are a group with many talents; storyteller, graphic designer, business women and artists and we have one thing in common:
A passion to see public art in our community of Sonora, California.

 

Sonora has a farmers market, as many communities do. Our market is a place to gather, to share, and to BE a community. We have many vendors that have been attending our market for 9 years or more. One of those vendors was Ed/Eleazar Rodriquez. Ed brought flowers to the market every Saturday. Flowers were not all that Ed brought. He brought joy to all that met him. He lifted spirits and created memories. One Saturday in September Ed was killed in a car accident on his way home from our market. Our community is still heartbroken.

After three sleepless nights Sarah and Laurie both came up with the same idea about how we could commemorate Ed, our colorful farmers market and add public art to our community. A MURAL with Ed’s image and an image of the market to be enjoyed all year long!

Our first hurdle was our local government giving their stamp of approval. On April 8, 2013, after jumping through all the necessary hoops, in front of a PACKED HOUSE our Design Review Committee, in a unanimous vote, gave the OK for our MURAL!

Judy Grossman, a well seasoned muralist, is our Master Artist. She has created a beautiful design. We intend to paint our mural in one day- maybe two. Professional Artists, with the help of our local young student Artists will paint in the mural.

This will be an EVENT to remember! Live music, food, dancing, kids activities.

 

 

With your financial contribution we can make this mural event a reality.  

We will use the money we raise for paint, brushes, scaffolding, painting surface (smooth aluminum panels), permits, insurance for now and the future, fundraising and event costs. We estimate this mural to cost $7,000 to $10,000. Our goal is to raise more than that... $15,000 so that we can have seed money to start a foundation to help create more public art and murals for our community in the future.

With your financial contribution also come some perks. We are giving away stickers and market bags with our logo and posters of our mural design. And for you big spenders we offer the opportunity of a gourmet dinner with the Committee and the Artist. Includes food and wine for yourself and three of your best people! And we are even including a signed framed poster!

This project will bring more than a lasting memory of Ed. This mural will create a sense of community. Artists’ young and old, volunteers, musicians, spectators will come together to create something that we will ALL be PROUD OF!

People underestimate the power of public art. This art project has the potential to inspire people in our community to participate and interact.

There are so many ways you can help.

You can help with dollars, with time, with your network of friends and word of mouth. Another way you can help is by using the share tools here on Indiegogo. Help us spread the word and help us meet our financial goals.

Our painting days are September 28 and 29, 2013.

We have fundraisers scheduled for May 14 and August 24.

PLEASE check the website for the most up to date details.

 

Our website is http://www.mural-in-a-day-sonora.org and our Facebook link https://www.facebook.com/MuralInADaySonora

PLEASE help us spread the word.

story:
UPDATE: AS OF 1/28/2013

 

Hi friends! GUESS WHAT? We have REACHED OUR GOAL!!!!! PRAISE THE LORD! Yep, the Lord blessed us with a 2 day or WHILE SUPPLIES last sale over the weekend. I went ahead and swooped up a computer with better specs and for $150 less this past weekend.

I am so excited and thankful! I will provide full details in an upcoming video along with the receipt of purchase and sale info! THANK YOU ALL for helping our sister out. May the Lord Jesus reward each and every one of you!

GraceTruthTeacher

 

-------------------------------------------------------------------------------------

Hi Guys!

 

Thank you for taking the time to view our project. Please know that we appreciate you and ANY contributions you can make. Please note that our dear sister has not asked or solicited our help. However, we would love for this to be a wonderful surprise and show of appreciation to someone who has given so much to others.

 

We are asking for 100 people to give $5.00 or any amount that the Lord leads you to give. Anonymous donations are allowed. If you can not give at this time we understand FULLY. We only ask that you share this video with others who know and love our dear sister Yvette. Thank you for your care and support of our dear sister in Christ!


Grace, Truth and Love,

 

Grace Truth Teacher

story:
-English version below-


Kalender 2014 - Walensee & Umgebung / 

Calendar 2014 - Lake Walensee 

Es wird ein Kalender mit Landschaftsaufnahmen vom Walensee & Sarganserland, Kanton St. Gallen, Schweiz erstellt. Format des Kalenders ist A4 und bietet genügend Platz zum Eintragen von kurzen Terminen oder Geburtstagen.

Dieser Kalender ist das Ergebnis von viel Freude am Fotografieren. Diese möchte ich gerne weitergeben. Es freut mich ausserordentlich, wenn ich mit meinen Bildern ein Lächeln, einen kurzen Tagtraum oder eine schöne Erinnerung ins Gedächtnis rufen kann! 

Gedruckt wird der Kalender auf 170g A4 Papier mit Spiralbindung und Aufhängung.


Beispielseite des Kalenders


Weitere Bilder des Kalenders


Druckkosten finanzieren - 12 Monate Freude 

Ich habe die flexible Kampagnen-Form von Indiegogo gewählt. Dies bedeutet, dass der Kalender auf jeden Fall gedruckt wird - Sie können sich also sicher sein, auch einen zu erhalten wenn sie entsprechend perken. Es geht kein Geld "verloren"

Sollten die Druckkosten gedeckt sein und noch Überschuss vorhanden sein, so werde ich dieses in meine Fotoausrüstung investieren.


Weitere Hilfe ohne etwas zu kaufen

Der Erfolg dieser Kampagne wird vom Bekanntheitsgrad abhängen. Daher würde ich mich riesig freuen, wenn Sie diese Seite an möglicherweise interessierte Menschen weiterleiten könnten. Per Mail, per Facebook, google+, Twitter.... Nach Möglichkeit Bitte die Teilen-Funktion auf dieser Seite nutzen.

Ich weiss jede Hilfe sehr zu schätzen. Vielen, vielen Dank!


English:

I love Photography. I like it very much, if  I can make you smile by watching my pictures. Therefore i will produce a Calendar 2014 with landscape photos from Lake Walensee and surrounding. 

The calendar shows you pictures from Lake Walensee, Switzerland and let enough space for short entries. See the example above!  Size: 8.3x11.7 inches, printed on 170g Paper.

With this campaign i like to raise the print costs - If I earn more, I will go for better gear, camera needs an update :-) 

This campaign could only be succesfull, if it get known. So, i would really apprechiate it, if you could spread this page via Email, facebook, google+, twitter.... Please use the sharing-tools on this page!

Thank you very much!

story: On June 19th 2014 the world lost a star and a lot of people lost someone special. I always promised my friend Matty that if something ever happened I would do what I could for his family and this is me trying to fulfill that promise. His parents would like to have swing and plaque placed in a local park for all of his friends and family visit and remember him as the awesome person he was. I don't have any perks to offer except my gratitude and the gratitude of his family. Thank you for taking the time to read this. Have a wonderful day.

story:
Welcome! 

My name is Rachel Teannalach. I am a landscape painter in Boise, Idaho. Hanging right inside the door to my studio is a drawing I did in kindergarten with a caption that reads, "When I grow up I want to be an artist." I now do professionally what I dreamt of doing for 28 of my 33 years. Making steps forward in an art career is challenging, and sometimes artists need a little extra help to take risks.

My campaign is to raise money for my membership in a new gallery. Gallery five18 is a newly renovated exhibition space on Americana Boulevard around the corner from the Linen District in downtown Boise. The gallery operates on a membership basis, which means that instead of paying the standard 50% gallery commission on sales, artists will pay a monthly membership fee. While this is a fantastic opportunity for artists to retain more of the revenue from their work, it is also requires taking the risk in committing to the membership dues each year. This is where you can help. By supporting my campaign, you can become a sponsor of my membership at Gallery five18, helping me to take this important leap in my career as an artist.


About my work

For the last several years, my work has focused on collaborations with conservation groups here in Idaho. In 2012 I partnered with Advocates for the West, a non-profit environmental law firm representing conservation groups in Idaho and beyond. Currently I am in my second year of collaboration with Idaho Conservation League, this year as the organization’s first Artist in Residence.  These projects, which help support conservation work, have taken me all over Idaho and allowed me to discover and paint many of its threatened and beautiful landscapes. The images I create are a benefit to partner organizations, which not only receive a percentage of the sales of original work, but have access to use of images in their promotional material. This way the inspiration I find in the landscapes of Idaho and beyond helps spread support and awareness for conservation issues. 


About Gallery five18

Gallery five18 is the brainchild of veteran artists and gallery owners, Mark and Jerri Lisk. It is a beautifully renovated industrial space, with an expansive main exhibition room and several smaller adjacent rooms. Each month the gallery will feature a new exhibition in the main space – either a solo show of one of the artists’ work, or a twice yearly group show. At all times, each artist will have smaller works available in one of the smaller rooms of the gallery. My first solo show at Gallery five18 will be in November, featuring paintings of the Boise Foothills completed as Idaho Conservation League's 2014 Artist in Residence.


How my campaign works

I am offering a variety of ways to become a sponsor of my first year at Gallery five18. The options include purchasing one of three sizes of original oil paintings, purchasing a limited edition print of one of these paintings, or buying an annual membership to the yoga classes I will be teaching in the gallery after each new exhibition is installed each month. Yoga memberships can be shared, so if you are out of town you can that month's class along to a friend. In the selection of prints and originals, I have included works of both Idaho and California, as well as prints of one of my most loved kaleidoscope paintings, Ganesha. Should I surpass my goal, I will apply extra funds to purchasing materials and creating work for my November show.

Sponsors at every level will be invited to a Sponsor Appreciation Party this summer (date TBA). Sponsors who purchase an original painting will be recognized as sponsors during my November 2014 solo show. Those who purchase a 24"x48" custom painting will be offered the opportunity to hold one company or private event at the gallery during the sponsorship year (scheduled through the gallery manager).

Your contribution to my membership at Gallery five18 will help me continue creating paintings of the landscapes we love here in Idaho. Your support will also help me continue collaborating with conservation organizations in Idaho and beyond to keep these amazing landscapes in the hearts and minds of those able to help protect them.

story:
Hello and thank you for looking at my campaign.

My name is Kevin Harris and I have always been attracted to anything artistic. My artistic endeavors began at age 7 when I was first introduced to comic books. The imagery and creativity of these artists just amazed my young mind.  I began copying what I saw and before long my teachers, realizing my talents, began encouraging me. For the last 15 years I have supplemented my income as a mid-management professional by painting portraits with very good results.

My work has been featured in Art&beyond magazine on multiple occasions and is published in a book titled Living Artists Today.

This campaign is about a couple of things

·  Opening a gallery / studio has been a dream of mine for some time. Currently, my dining room doubles as my art studio and a studio will allow me to really do what I love, which is to promote the arts. Our schools need more of an art presence. Young adults need to know that there is a future in creating beautiful things.

·  I want to create a space where children and adults can learn about art and the creative process.

As an artist these things are very important to me because I find that there is a void in the public school system as it relates to art education and career planning. Art has been a staple in my life since I was a small child so I want to encourage children and adults to pursue their art dreams, no matter how big or small those dreams may be.

What We Need & What You Get

My goals are lofty and here is where the funds will go

To help me start the studio where I have the space and resources to host workshops for children as well as adults, I am asking for $30,000.  This includes all art materials, a printer capable of reproducing fine art prints, easels and chairs, to name a few things.

The perks are a labor of love as all the art I have created over the past year specifically have enormous meaning to me. My growth as an artist has been within that time frame and it has produced some of my most meaningful work

If I do not meet the entire goal, the studio will open, and I still plan on hosting these workshops, so the funds will be used for canvasses, paint, brushes and other art supplies to get us started.

The Impact

As an artist I have had the pleasure of interacting with some wonderful people who have encouraged me to proceed. I want to be that voice that encourages young artists everywhere and opening the studio/gallery is the springboard to that. My artist supporting artists series has set a foundation that I want to build on.  By leveraging these relationships and bringing in my talented friends for shows and classes I want to  encourage young people that there is a career path through creativity or inspire the young at heart to use their art as a creative outlet.

I have successfully managed businesses my whole adult life as a supervisor at various companies and I am looking forward to doing the same for this community based organization.

"Why do I tag my paintings with ArtIZtherapy? I have not lived an easy life, in fact, there is no such thing. Some of us are more challenged in that regard and ArtIZtherapy was inspired by my ability to escape the daily insanity of life. Immersing myself wholeheartedly in creating these pieces for you I am at peace in the creative process. My upbringing was harsh, my childhood, joyless.  I love what I do because I am therapeutically cleansing my self of many demons from the past." Kevin Harris

Other Ways You Can Help

I understand that not everyone reading this will be in a position to assist financially, but you can still help.

Spread the word! Post the link on your social media page. This sight has great share tools.

If you are with the media, contact me, I would love to tell you about how I want to enrich the lives of young artists and encourage the creativity of adults.

I can also tell you how I have produced a new piece of art almost every day for the better part of a year.

Thank you for taking the time to read this and thanks in advance for your contribution.

story:
Our campaign is finished, please go to http://pixeli.st or write us at paint@pixeli.st for more information. 


Pixelist: we paint your pixels

Send us your instagram (or digital photo) and we’ll send you a hand-made painting of that image. Yep, a hand-made, bespoke oil painting by one of our professional artists. 

At Pixelist, you’re the art director: you provide the vision and we take care of execution. Please take a look at our photo gallery to get an idea of the versatility and quality of our paintings.  

To spread the word about Pixelist, we're offering a limited supply of paintings at huge discounts on IndieGoGo!

NOTE: YOU DO NOT NEED TO UPLOAD YOUR PHOTO WHEN YOU CONTRIBUTE. WE WILL GET YOUR PHOTO BY EMAIL AFTER THE CAMPAIGN ENDS.

Instead of some mass-marketed, generic landscape or still life, we offer handcrafted paintings of images that mean something to you. That’s the magic of commissioned paintings — and why we’re proud to introduce them as a unique compliment to instagram. 

How to Order

Decide on the photo you’d like to get painted:

  • Instagrams are square, so they go with one of the 12X12 perks
  • Normal photos are rectangular, so they go with the 12X16 inch perks
  • If you’d like a larger painting, either photo shape is fine

Check out:

  • Click on the contribute now button
  • Click on the perk you’d like (the amount will automatically be added)
  • Enter the address for where you want the painting shipped
  • Pay

Please remember:

  • We will ask for your photo after the campaign is finished; you do not need to upload it (see inforgraphic below for details)
  • You can only buy one painting at a time. 

Why We're Here

We have a simple set of goals for this campaign. We want to:

  • spread the word about Pixelist
  • fund the development of our website
  • fund our plans to expand capacity

We're asking for your help. But in return we're offering you great paintings at the lowest prices you'll find anywhere!

 

The Nitty-Gritty: Fulfillment & Restrictions

 

After you purchase your painting "perk", and our 30-day campaign comes to an end, you'll get an email from us requesting your photo (and painting size for those who ordered "Anything Goes" or "Cultured Baller" rewards). Simply attach your instagram or digital photo to your reply and we'll have everything we need! Note: you can only use photos that you own or have the express permission of the owner to use. 

Please keep in mind that your photo should either be square (all instagrams are) or rectangular with dimensions of 4 by 3 (the normal dimensions for most photos). Our initial email to you will give simple directions for photo cropping to the correct dimensions. Don't worry, if there are any issues with the dimensions of your photo or how to attach it we are always available on email to help.

There are limits to any painter's dexterity that make it extremely difficult to paint 10 people or a fruit stand on a small (12X12 inch) canvas. This is why we've set limits on the number of people or animals allowed in photos depending on the size of the painting. For all 12X12 or 12X16 paintings we allow a maximum of two people, two animals, or one person and one animal (ie, three is too many at these sizes). Don’t worry, we’ll let you know if your photo is too complex and help you figure out a good alternative.


Please use your best judgment in choosing your photo. To provide an example, something like this is about as intricate an image as we can accept.

 

 

 

This image, on the other hand, is much too intricate to paint well on a small canvas. 

 Thanks for supporting us!
story_txt:

Pixelist: we paint your pixels
Send us your instagram (or digital photo) and we’ll send you a hand-made painting of that image. Yep, a hand-made, bespoke oil painting by one of our professional artists. 
At Pixelist, you’re the art director: you provide the vision and we take care of execution. Please take a look at our photo gallery to get an idea of the versatility and quality of our paintings.  
To spread the word about Pixelist, we're offering a limited supply of paintings at huge discounts on IndieGoGo!
NOTE: YOU DO NOT NEED TO UPLOAD YOUR PHOTO WHEN YOU CONTRIBUTE. WE WILL GET YOUR PHOTO BY EMAIL AFTER THE CAMPAIGN ENDS.



Instead of some mass-marketed, generic landscape or still life, we offer handcrafted paintings of images that mean something to you. That’s the magic of commissioned paintings — and why we’re proud to introduce them as a unique compliment to instagram.

story:
The Art Ashram

The Art Ashram is a proposed monthly one day art event featuring both a traditional gallery showing as well as an interactive component designed to be the beginning of a dialog.

We are looking to fund our first four shows and get this event going!

The Concept 

The idea behind the Art Ashram project is rooted in the idea that art can and has been used as a way to both communicate and obtain those subtle spiritual experiences that many would label mystical. Through the use of art it is our desire to begin a dialog. A dialog between artist and patron, man and women, parent and child, etc.

We feel that art is that perfect symbolic language that both artist and mystic understand, furthermore it is that language that can be and should be accessible to everyone. The Art Ashram’s purpose is to begin, encourage and support this dialog and facilitate an environment of creative freedom and spiritual transcendence. We want to create an environment free from dogma and judgement, but instead encourage an open exploration and discussion of both art and spirit.

Ultimately we want to create a beautiful, meditative and innovative art experience that will serve patron, artist and venue alike. We wish to have the supportive environment and creativity of Andy Warhol's Plastic Factory, combined with the meditative atmosphere of a Temple space. Hence, we want to truly create an Art Ashram.

The How 

The show itself will take place once a month centered on a theme. The work of several artists will be shown, all contributing to the theme.  Together the art will create a tapestry of concepts and perhaps even contradictions around the subject.  This part of the Art Ashram will resemble an art opening with a meditative atmosphere.

The other aspect of the Art Ashram, the Warholian atmosphere in which patrons can actively participate, is interactive.  They can paint, draw, write, sing, and read poetry based on the theme.  Whole families can join in the dialog and draw and paint together.  Combined with the art that is being displayed, this will create an entire artistic and transcendent experience, the whole event becoming more than an art show and more of a shared experience.

Prospective Shows 

The themes chosen for each event are vague enough to encompass many traditions, yet specific enough to create a unified show. The Ashram itself will refrain from preaching for or against any particular belief system. The point of the project is to open the door for open conversations. This all being said, the first year of shows should include the following themes:

1. Emptiness is Form 2. Unity 3. Duality 4. Balance 5. Earth, Air, Fire and Water 6. Our Body is our Temple 7. As Above so Below 8. Nature of Happiness 9. Cyclical Nature 10. Death 11. Rebirth 12. Know Thyself

We feel this art event could become a strong force in the art and spiritual community and serve to bring these two strong communities together. Furthermore, we feel that this event could serve as a doorway for those who are “art curious”. An open and encouraging atmosphere such as this may spawn the next Da Vinci or Ram Dass.

What the money is for:

We want to be able to take complete control of the venue. So, renting a venue is the best idea for our needs. The venues that we are interested in rent for $150 to $250. Our goal of $1,100 is to pay rent for the first four shows, purchase art supplies for the interactive portion of the event, and purchasing food and drinks.

We look forward to working with you on the Art Ashram project.

http://photo-monk.com/art-ashram

story:
Who We Are

The MARZ Project (Media & Arts Resource Zone) is a free, nonprofit drop-in digital media studio where young artists learn valuable tools for creative expression in audio, video, and graphic art.  Under the direction of our professional instructors, students can work on their own projects, or participate in job training.  Local businesses receive low cost marketing materials, while MARZ media makers develop job skills.

What We Need

Our Indiegogo project is to build a better production suite for our students and bump up our media production services.  We want the skills students learn and the jobs they're able to take on to be competitive of the media landscape of today, but in order for our students to produce professional projects, they need access to professionals tools.  This is why we need your help!

The MARZ Project Mission

Operating since 1997, our mission is to "provide a safe space for young people engaging in healthy self-expression, confidence-building, leadership skills, and a creative and just community."  Throughout our 15 years of operation, we've managed to make sure that all MARZ Project resources and workshops are free to Humboldt County youth.

What we Do

Every Tuesday through Friday after school, students representing a cross section of local youth from very diverse backgrounds come to MARZ to hang out, make friends, work on creative projects at their own pace, and to make lasting and positive contributions to their communities.  They have access to a small music recording studio with a variety of instruments, a computer lab with equipment and editing software for video and digital graphics projects, as well as an "analog art room" to reinforce studio art fundamentals like drawing and painting.  

Students who want to take their skills to the next level can join the Media Crew where they're trained by our core staff instructors and partnered on paying projects for agencies and nonprofit organizations in the community.  They earn money while learning to produce media projects that meet professional standards.  Project skills include:  video and radio PSA's, event posters/flyers, logo designs, event coverage and documentary-style pieces.  Some crew members also DJ and perform their music at fundraisers and art openings, and put on all ages drug/alcohol free dance parties for other local youth.  Our goal is to send them out into the world with skills that they can use to do work they enjoy, meaningful work that contributes to their community.  Here is a partial list of projects MARZ student artists have worked on to earn money and serve the community: 


  • Northern California Indian Development Council: Elders Dinner event coverage
  • Humboldt County Mental Health Department: 1st place winner in poster contest
  • YouthAbility youth job-training development support:  3 video projects
  • Humboldt County Department of Heath and Human Services: Graphics layout project 
  • Raven Project: mini documentary about safe spaces for LGBT youth 
  • Spare Change: 3 yrs performance coverage/documentary video
  • Humboldt County Office of Education/TAPESTRY: HIV/STD prevention PSA series (TV, radio, print) 
  • Humboldt Economic Development Department:  Youth job-training program/3-part documentary
  • Boys and Girls Club: Video interviews for 40 year anniversary celebration
  • Teen Court: poster design
  • ASAP Substance Abuse Prevention Program: logo and graphic design

MARZ All-Stars!

Raven came in to the MARZ Project five years ago, to challenge her fear of performing in front of others, and now works as a digital media assistant for the project.  Raven produces public service announcements, organizes alcohol and drug free music concerts, creates and distributes flyers, shoots and edits video projects, helps students in the computer and music recording lab, and yes, writes and performs original music regularly now.

"I can't imagine where, or even who, I'd be without the MARZ Project," Raven says.  "I've learned a lot of skills that help me feel really confident about what it is I have to offer the world.  I also volunteer for the North Star Quest Camp as a mentor for seventh and eighth grade girls.  I believe I can make a positive change in my community." 

Felicia came to MARZ to learn video skills.  She joined our media crew two weeks later.  She's now working on a documentary style piece about being a Hmong dancer and exploring the importance of preserving her cultural traditions.  Her story is thoughtful, well researched, visually rich, and we know it will raise awareness of the Hmong culture in our community.  

Taylor came to MARZ when she was 15.  She's been on her own since she was 16.  When she wasn't doing homework, she was usually hanging out at MARZ.  Now she's the lead videographer on our media crew, studying film at Humboldt State University...and still getting straight A's!  She recently got an entry level position at a local TV station.  We like to think that the caring, support, and sense of family here at MARZ had a little to do with that.

How YOU Can Help!

Like most small grassroots projects, we have the skills and the heart, and struggle with limited and always changing funding.  Our equipment is outdated.  We spend a lot of time doing work-arounds on our ten year old video editing computers, and not enough time editing.  We're able to get some software updated, but some is hopelessly out of date.  Our recording studio, although a great resource for drop in musicians who wouldn't otherwise have access to music technology, is built on worn out hardware and isn't ready to support professional level projects.  We also need to replace our old PA system, one of our primary ways our music students interact with the community and help raise funds for the project.  We often have to borrow gear from community/staff members to get jobs done!

Having access to up to date equipment will dramatically increase the quality of our productions, and provide more opportunities for our students to take on real world projects.  These projects will also provide the MARZ Project with ongoing revenues, thereby boosting our attempts at making MARZ truly sustainable.  See our complete tech plan for a breakdown on what we need.  

To learn more about the MARZ Project, please visit these links!

http://www.cac.ca.gov/artworks

http://www.youtube.com/watch?v=A7gJgxcQMeE

http://www.youtube.com/user/MARZproject

https://www.facebook.com/MARZ.Project

Thank You for supporting our Indiegogo Project!

Sincerely, the MARZ Project Crew


Eileen McGee, BA in Journalism, minor in Women's Studies, works with youth in digital media and video productions; independent producer for local media projects

Cory Goldman, BS in Music, multi instrumentalist with years of performing, teaching, and international touring experience

Kati Texas, Ink People Artist in Residence since 2006, muralist, graphic designer

Jerome Bearbower, MA in Sociology, Stilt-Walker, Development Coordinator 

Libby Maynard, Executive Director of the Ink People Center for the Arts


Technical Plan


Music & Audio 


Powered PA speakers with stands and cables 

USB audio interface

Condenser and dynamic mics

Pop filter, music stands, and other misc. music supplies 

Soundproofing

Repair tools (solder, pliers)


Digital Graphics


Software:  Adobe Photoshop CS6 / Multiple Install Licenses (4)

Digital Camera:  Kodak Easy/Share Z5010 Digital Camera


Video Production 


High def video camera(s) with memory card technology 

Mac computer and peripherals with video and digital media software   

Adobe Premiere video editing suite 

Video Specific Microphone


Perks Up Close!


Graphic for Bumper Sticker and T-Shirt! 





Local Artist Made Tarot Deck!

http://www.humboldtartiststarot.blogspot.com/



Example of Cartoon Portrait/Logo!

story:
Who Are We?

We’re just two people a 1000 miles away (one in Florida, one in Pennsylvania) that bumped into each other by happenstance on Tumblr. 

After getting to know each other and sharing glimpses into our lives for a little over a year we finally met in New York and spent two days touring the familiar sites and enjoying each other's company. Though I was out to myself, friends and colleagues, she gave me the courage to come out to my family after years of silently fearing their rejection.

Neither of us knew a year ago that we would meet in person one day and feel a definite connection. Even before we left New York, we knew time had flown and that two days was just too short. It would be a gross understatement to just say I really like this girl, but I realllly like her and I want to surprise her around Valentine’s weekend with a longer visit to her home state. 

If you believe in love and magic, I need your help to make my goal a reality!


So, like, a Modern Juliet & Juliet?

Basically.
Her name is Chelsea and I’m Bri and we live about 1,013 miles away. 

We're real people with real stories. We both love good poetry, good music, and good art, among other things. I’m a recent grad with a degree in art who does freelance design, and she’s studying to be a surgeon while working full time. (Did you notice that rhymed?)

After graduating, like a lot of recent grads, I was faced with a slow job market and a hefty student loan bill. I’ve been nothing by fortunate and cannot be more grateful in terms of the opportunities and leniencies afforded to me, but finances have been an inhibiting and deterring factor in terms of making major moves like travel. So I decided to take a gap year (a year in between entering a long-term career or enrolling in an MFA program) to hone my art portfolio and recuperate from school while working as a freelancer. Although money has been tight, it didn't stop me from wanting to meet Chelsea.

It was by good fortune, and our supportive families, that we were able to meet face-to-face for the first time in New York while she visited the popular sites. We joked about how crazy and surreal it’s all been, and it's true. A year ago, neither of us could have guessed we'd be where we are now.

And even though we're so far away, I still feel just as close to her.


How You Can Help

The campaign goal of $800 will pay for the cost of one round trip ticket from Harrisburg (MDT) to Tampa (TPA) and an Economy rental car for four days (airline taxes, rental fees, and other surcharges included).

That's it--it's that simple!

I’m not asking for money to support anything else; I just need a ticket to Tampa on the path of least resistance and people who believe in magic and real life fairytales. 

If you can help in any way in my effort to see Chelsea again, either by donating or signal-boosting, I will be forever grateful. 
Who knows what the future may hold.

You could quite literally help a growing romance blossom into something bigger!

The campaign goal of $800 will pay for the cost of one round trip ticket from Harrisburg (MDT) to Tampa (TPA) and an Economy rental car for four days (airline taxes, rental fees, and other surcharges included).
That's it--it's that simple!
I’m not asking for money to support anything else; I just need a ticket to Tampa on the path of least resistance and people who believe in magic and real life fairytales. 
If you can help in any way in my effort to see Chelsea again, either by donating or signal-boosting, I will be forever grateful. Who knows what the future may hold.
You could quite literally help a growing romance blossom into something bigger!

story:
What's (re)activate?

(re)activate is a one-night public art exhibition that is scheduled to take place in a vacant parking lot at U & 9th Street, NW on Saturday, March 15th from 5:30 - 9:30pm.

Why (re)activate?

In having free access to a vacant parking lot in the center of the city for one weekend, we saw an incredible opportunity to:

  1. improve the aesthetics and utility of a vacant space
  2. promote and exhibit the work of DC artists
  3. create a space where people can inspire and be inspired

How to (re)activate?

Naturally, a project like this requires special technology and equipment needs, such as:

  1. renting a 10K luminance projector + insurance coverage
  2. paying the exhibiting artists a stipend for their artistic contributions
  3. purchasing building materials, paint, paint brushes, tape and electric cords

A donation of any size - be it $10, $25, $100 or more - will makes a tremendous difference in helping us produce this out-of-the-ordinary art experience!

Thank you for your generous support in (re)activating Washington, DC! 


Check us out Facebook join us for a drink at American Ice Company on Thursday, March 6th!  From 6 - 8 pm a portion of the proceeds from drink specials will go directly to the project. Invite all your friends!

story:
Our Aim is to dress Kingston town for IYAFestival, bringing your town alive. We will run workshops on Graffiti, Felting, Body Casting, Mask Making and more! We will bring art work into 12 venues through town and install public artwork and murals throughout the town.

We will truly celebrate visual art and increase awareness locally that a festival IS happening, making a visual connection between the IYAF venues, as well as other hot spots for possible audience. Kingston will come alive with art!

Everything we will provide will be free. So your donations mean we can run drop - in workshops for All Ages across a range of mediums, open to anyone that wants to learn a new skill, or just have fun. We will also be taking the workshops into schools, to ensure the local school children are part of the festival. 

As well as large outdoor street art and graffiti murals, created live by professional artists, we will also have carefully curated selections of work inside festival venues, bars and cafes, including the work made specifically for the festival during Workshop week. There will also be a Sculpture Park similarly to last year. To bring these elements together and really dress the town we will hang banners throughout the main shopping street celebrating the artwork featured in the festival and unveil a large scale map in the Market Square. Bird feet will be painted on the floor too, to guide festival-goers between venues. We will even project film based work outdoors every night!

We want to do this because we have been involved in the International Youth Arts Festival for the last few years. and it has been an important factor in our developing of professional skills in the arts. IYAF has given us the opportunity to put on events and share our creativity with a wider public. This year we want to bring back the skills we have learnt to make visual arts a bigger and better part of IYAF 2014, and bring in as much participatory elements the wider public can really get involved in the festival.

With the help of the funds raised by this Indiegogo, we will be able to afford the materials and artist expenses that will make this whole project possible.  No participating artists or project facilitators are being paid for their involvement in this project, this money will simply cover costs. To thank artists for getting involved we hope to host an exhibition following the festival featuring their artwork and documentation of the festival.

We want to bring this ambitious idea into fruition because we believe in bringing fantastic, innovative and exciting art to the public and making great art accessible by all. With your help we can make a real visual impact in Kingston this summer, and more importantly bring art to you, and provide an opportunity for everyone to get involved!

If we don't reach our entire goal, we will do as much as we can with the funds raised. We are also hoping to acquire some funding for this project, and only if we both get your help, and obtain the funding, will we be able to see through our ambitious plans! The project will go ahead whatever we raise, but at a much smaller scale. Your help means we can fulfill our ambitious plans to bring Kingston alive with art. So every little helps!

story:
Summary
Astrid Oudheusden is a Dutch painter who has been recognized locally as well as Internationally with several solo exhibitions in Europe and sales across the globe 
She started  the 1000 faces portraits series after gaduating from Art school as a challenge in discovering and representing her inner self inspired by the Lou Reed song "Trade In" 
Rarely an Artist has managed since the the generalization of mirrors and the risky exercise it generated the self portrait; to express so much and push the limits so far.
It's important to show the 1000 faces in Paris as Astrid has special ties to that city
As a contributor you will help show an important and large body of Astrid's work in it's integrity for the very first time 

What We Need & What You Get
We need 10000 Euros to organize and promote a great exhibition, all contributors are invited to the opening and to the after party in Paris
Our unique perks will be a choice of Postcards, Giclee Art Print or even an original Painting

Postcards

Giclee Print

Original Oil Paintings

All the funds will go into organizing the exhibition and if we don't reach our entire goal people will get the art anyway

The Impact
What makes this approach different is the fact that we will touch people globally and at the same time be able to show the art locally in Paris

* Note to those of you who wish to pay by credit card, you can do so directly without having a PayPal account but please be aware that when processing your payment PayPal has the create an account box ticked on by default so if you do not want to create a PayPal account don't forget to uncheck that option

story:
An American Water Margin

curated by ARTRA Curatorial and Sijia Chen

ARTISTS:

Sijia Chen, Kenturah Davis, Durden & Ray, Mark Dutcher, Jay Erker, Roni Feldman, Jon Flack, Kio Griffith, Luis Hernandez, Ben Jackel, Kiel Johnson, William Kaminski, Marcos Lutyens, Claudia Parducci, Max Presneill, Christopher Russell, Theodore Svenningsen, Grant Vetter, Steven Wolkoff

Opening reception: Sept 11th, 2014, 3 pm.

UCity Art Museum of Guangzhou Academy of Fine Arts, 168 Waihuan West Road, University City, Panyu District, Guangzhou, China

———————————————————————

Curators’ Word

Each of us finds our ethical position slowly through a combination of family values, community norms and cultural signifiers. These influences bring together sets of potential positions for us to sift through and begin the process of decision making that leads us to adulthood. The sources for much of these influences can be varied and of varying quality but we seem to make out OK in the end, or at least most of us do.

When we began the process of building this exhibition we began with the notion of the difficulty in translating one language to the other. There is an immediate problem in communication that seemed valuable for us to focus on. Not just spoken and written language either, but also how the Western visual art tradition has developed and the complexities of cultural transmission from one set of cultures to another set. What do we share and what is alien between us?

With television and film being such influential purveyors of myriad ideas and approaches many ways of seeing and thinking about the world can be gleamed from them. Many of our conceptions of the world start here. These were often from various points around the globe which perhaps can provide a wider education on the ideas of right and wrong. One of these programs was a 1973 Japanese version of a classic Chinese story called Water Margin, written originally by Shi Nai’an. When formulating this exhibition and finding linkages to situate the show’s themes my co-curators, Sijia Chen and Kio Griffith, and I, discovered that we had all watched the same program as children while growing up in the UK, China and Japan/USA respectively. Half way across the world and we shared a common root in growing up. Even the quote which began each episode became pregnant with meaning for us as children, even if we could not quite decipher it -

“Do not despise the snake for having no horns, for who is to say he will not become a Dragon?”

Each week the heroes of the tale would struggle for right over wrong. Set during the Song Dynasty the outlaws fight injustice and eventually are granted amnesty and then sent to resist foreign invaders and rebel forces, ironically. That the outlaws of Water Margin ultimately failed should not distract us from the central message that the struggle is worthy and that we are made up of the decisions we make regardless of whether it is the easy one or guaranteed success. It is an existential approach that values the struggle over the result. Just like the actual act of making art, the theme of the story strikes a chord with artists everywhere......This is the basis for our exhibition - the languages of contemporary art that we investigate in the service of both the exploration of visual languages and the role they play in the social field. We hope to direct the Chinese audience’s attention to the importance, for the artists, of making art that is talking about the history of aesthetic development in Western art alongside urgent matters to address socially in the US.

And so the artists for this show were selected. They address themes which respond to issues concerned with this transmission - of ideals and of ethics, while acknowledging that being Human, in itself, supplies some of the elements needed to cross some barriers. They self-reflexively address the inherent problematic issues that arise in the act of translation. There is present in these works a hope for the future, in attempting to communicate across those barriers between us, that place value in the attempt itself and hope that with perserverence the hurdle will eventually be overcome. Using a Los Angeles art vernacular, as the Water Margin was in Chinese vernacular, the art works reveal complex layerings of thought that encompasses both philosophic and aesthetic concerns with an optimism for Humanity that calls out to unite us all.

story:
The Bay City Arts Center (BCAC) is located in Bay City, Oregon off of Hwy 101. As a 501(c)(3) organization, our mission is to establish and maintain a community arts center and to design and administer programs and events that support creativity and reach out to the youth and adults of Tillamook County.

Currently we are seeking support for the replacement of our 90 year old pillars on the eastern side of our building. This historic Masonic Lodge is owned by the BCAC organization, and it is up to us to secure all of the necessary funding to complete the repairs. As a cornerstone facility and organization to both the community and the arts field, it is necessary for the BCAC to complete these repairs before the devastating winter winds hit and compromise the building's structure beyond repair.

We kindly appeal to individuals and families throughout our home region and beyond to show support and help us by donating pennies, dollars, and more to our cause so we can continue to provide quality creative education and instruction, a place for community gatherings and meetings, and a refuge for individuals of all ages in times of natural disaster.

The BCAC is comprised of a diverse Board of Directors and volunteer staff united to providing arts to our community. Our program offerings are unique, inclusive and thoughtful to the needs of our region and many originate as ideas and contributions from our dedicated membership.

We serve as a strong community partner to many local non-profits providing a place to meet and fundraise. We also provide a safe and secure shelter location for community members during times of disaster, including support during the devastating wind storms that are prevalent in our rural coastal region, and as a facility with a certified commercial kitchen we are able to provide healthy, warm food to those in need.

The BCAC fosters strong collaboration efforts involving the Tillamook School Districts #9 and #56. The center sponsors student art shows, youth Open Mic Nights, and works with both at-risk and developmentally disabled youth designing programs targeted to their individual and specific needs.

We have received numerous recognition awards over the years due to our community commitment including the Tillamook County Future’s Council Cultural Recognition Award.

Now is the time to look towards the future or the arts in Rural America and show your support for this amazing and vibrant community arts center. Together we can assure that the Bay City Arts Center building will continue to provide arts education and community support for decades to come!

We will be hosting a pillar party with live music, food, dancing and fun on October 18th at 5pm at the Bay City Arts Center.

For more information about the organization and schedule of events please contact us at (503) 377-9620. Please provide support for this campaign online or mail checks to PO Box 3124 Bay City, OR 97107.

story:
Short Summary

Hello! My name is Megan Ramirez. I have been making art passionately as long as I can remember, starting with crayons. Now, at 17 years of age, I am every bit as enthusiastic about my art, having attended a magnent program called ArtQuest at Santa Rosa High School for two years and teaching kids younger than me to paint and draw part-time. 

I have applied to the summer precollege program at San Francisco Art Institute. I have been accepted to the program and received a $2,000 scholarship!

What We Need 

Even with the scholarship, I still need a little help to finish paying for the program. I have a goal of raising $1,000. All of the money will go to my mothers bank account, and we will pay for the program monthly out of there.

If I do not reach my funding goal here, all money donated will still be directed towards the program. I will find a way to make up the rest.

Any donation I recieve is whole heartedly appreciated!

The Impact

This program is important to me. It will allow me intimate and ample time with great artists and teachers, and with new medias. With this program I plan to build my technical and conceptual skills, as I become more independent, starting my career as an artist in the city and building an extensive portfolio that I can be proud of. I will continue to build on this portfolio after, with all of the knowledge I gain from this program, in my last year of high school in Advanced Placement (AP) Art class. 

I hope that with the knowledge I gain at this program I will make art that catches peoples attention, and they will listen. 

This financial help will be the catalyst in my journey as an independent artist.

story:
Hello! We’re Laiwan and Joni. Together we're working on a public art project in Vancouver, and invite you to become part of the process.

Commissioned by the Vancouver Heritage Foundation, CBC and JJ Bean Coffee, FOUNTAIN is a work by artist Laiwan exploring the metaphor of water and expressions of fluidity in our city’s built environment. For this, she’s collaborating with independent curator Joni Low and Centre A, a non-profit art space in Vancouver. FOUNTAIN has two parts: one, a large-scale printed artwork that will be mounted at the CBC Plaza. Two: a parallel web project that will become a crowd-sourced archive on fluidity and the nature of memory, which we’re seeking your support for. Both projects will be launched this March 2014! 

Our appeal to you 

We need your help in raising $1,500 by March 8, to help cover the technical and creative design for this web project. Centre A has generously offered to match this target amount, and will host this as a permanent artwork on their website! Your contributions will not only provide the support necessary to develop this important and engaging work; they will help make possible the creation of a virtual public space that all can participate in and contribute to once it's live!

In gratitude 

In recognition of your support, Laiwan is making a series of playful, limited edition works – including her ephemeral Single Square Haiku Poems and Love Demonstrously t-shirts. Two of her beautiful petal slides – shown recently in Presentation House Gallery’s c.1983 Part II exhibition - are also available!! The UBC Belkin Gallery has also collected prints from this series. Check out the sidebar for more details.

Thank you for supporting our project! Please share this link with your friends - each and every contribution helps make this happen. If you’re in Vancouver this March, we'd love to have you join us for the project’s opening reception. Please visit www.centrea.org over the next month for details on the launch date. All Indiegogo contributors will receive an e-invitation to the opening!

More about the project:

Drawing from Laiwan’s current research in the CBC media archives, FOUNTAIN’s interactive web project will be a poetic reflection on experimental fluidities, while also making connections between community groups that know fluidity through phenomena and memory: from streams and waterlines beneath present-day urban spaces, to information flow and the communities that convene in these urban and virtual realms. Open to public contributions, this crowd-sourced multimedia archive will show us how memory changes, drifts, and is preserved, in our digital age. What is lost in the shift from analogue to digital – and what is made possible?

About the team:

Laiwan is a Vancouver-based interdisciplinary artist, writer and educator with a wide-ranging practice that reflects her interests in poetics and philosophy. Her cross-disciplinary projects often investigate epistemology, phenomenology, somatic affect, technology and viral mobility.

Joni Low is a Vancouver-based independent curator and writer who is drawn to art that exists beyond conventional exhibition spaces—art that shifts and creates new understandings of the contemporary experience. Her writing has appeared in exhibition catalogues and in publications including Canadian Art, C Magazine, Fillip and Yishu. 

Centre A is Canada’s only public gallery devoted to contemporary art of the Asia-Pacific region. Established in 1999 and now located in Chinatown’s East Georgia Gallery Cluster, we have presented the works of over 300 Canadian and international artists and produced over 80 original projects. As a key piece of Vancouver’s cultural infrastructure, Centre A works with artists, curators and other cultural producers in the region to provide a platform for conversation, critical inquiry, and artistic experimentation.

The Vancouver Heritage Foundation is a charitable organization that actively supports the conservation of heritage buildings and structures in recognition of their contribution to the city’s economy, sustainability and culture. Through fundraising, educational outreach and relationship-building, they develop tools to aid in the conservation of heritage structures, and create on-going opportunities to access and learn about Vancouver’s heritage buildings.

Click here to learn more about The Wall at CBC Plaza

FOUNTAIN has two parts: one, a large-scale printed artwork that will be mounted at the CBC Plaza. Two: a parallel web project that will become a crowd-sourced archive on fluidity and the nature of memory, which we’re seeking your support for. Both projects will be launched this March 2014! Our appeal to you We need your help in raising $1,500 by March 8, to help cover the technical and creative design for this web project. Centre A has generously offered to match this target amount, and will host this as a permanent artwork on their website! Your contributions will not only provide the support necessary to develop this important and engaging work; they will help make possible the creation of a virtual public space that all can participate in and contribute to once it's live!In gratitude In recognition of your support, Laiwan is making a series of playful, limited edition works – including her ephemeral Single Square Haiku Poems and Love Demonstrously t-shirts. Two of her beautiful petal slides – shown recently in Presentation House Gallery’s c.1983 Part II exhibition - are also available!! The UBC Belkin Gallery has also collected prints from this series. Check out the sidebar for more details.Thank you for supporting our project! Please share this link with your friends - each and every contribution helps make this happen. If you’re in Vancouver this March, we'd love to have you join us for the project’s opening reception. Please visit www.centrea.org over the next month for details on the launch date. All Indiegogo contributors will receive an e-invitation to the opening!More about the project:Drawing from Laiwan’s current research in the CBC media archives, FOUNTAIN’s interactive web project will be a poetic reflection on experimental fluidities, while also making connections between community groups that know fluidity through phenomena and memory: from streams and waterlines beneath present-day urban spaces, to information flow and the communities that convene in these urban and virtual realms. Open to public contributions, this crowd-sourced multimedia archive will show us how memory changes, drifts, and is preserved, in our digital age. What is lost in the shift from analogue to digital – and what is made possible? About the team:Laiwan is a Vancouver-based interdisciplinary artist, writer and educator with a wide-ranging practice that reflects her interests in poetics and philosophy. Her cross-disciplinary projects often investigate epistemology, phenomenology, somatic affect, technology and viral mobility.Joni Low is a Vancouver-based independent curator and writer who is drawn to art that exists beyond conventional exhibition spaces—art that shifts and creates new understandings of the contemporary experience. Her writing has appeared in exhibition catalogues and in publications including Canadian Art, C Magazine, Fillip and Yishu. Centre A is Canada’s only public gallery devoted to contemporary art of the Asia-Pacific
region. Established in 1999 and now located in Chinatown’s East Georgia Gallery
Cluster, we have presented the works of over 300 Canadian and international
artists and produced over 80 original projects. 
As a key piece of Vancouver’s cultural infrastructure, Centre A works with artists, curators and other
cultural producers in the region to provide a platform for conversation,
critical inquiry, and artistic experimentation.
The Vancouver Heritage Foundation is a charitable organization that actively supports the conservation of heritage buildings and structures in recognition of their contribution to the city’s economy, sustainability and culture. Through fundraising, educational outreach and relationship-building, they develop tools to aid in the conservation of heritage structures, and create on-going opportunities to access and learn about Vancouver’s heritage buildings.Click here to learn more about The Wall at CBC Plaza

story:
Eleven American Indian artists from Oklahoma have been invited to participate in the 2011 exhibit of the Salon du Dessin et de la Peinture à l’Eau, being held Nov. 22-27, 2011, at the Grand Palais in Paris! 

 

OKLAHOMA ARTISTS

 

America Meredith

Anita Fields

Brent Greenwood

Dana Tiger

dg smalling

Joe Don Brave

Marla Skye

N. Scott Momaday

Yatika Fields

Edgar Heap of Birds

Tom Poolaw

 

 

FEATURED DANCER

 

Russ Tall Chief

 

These award-winning artists represent a cross-section of the best Oklahoma American Indian artists working in watercolor and paper, which is the genre of our respective salon.  The other four salons in the exhibitions are based in a variety of  media, such as oil on canvas, sculpture, and various other artistic expressions.  In order to participate in the exhibition, the artists need financial support for exhibition fees, shipping of art, insurance for their works, as well as funding to attend the exhibit. 

 

The artists will be accompanied by Russ Tall Chief, the featured dancer who is also independently curating the exhibition.  We would be honored and humbled by your financial support of this historic exhibition. 

 

Thank you in advance for your support. Please feel free to contact nativeartsaloninparis@gmail.com.

story:
Short Summary

The concept behind Local Art Love Is an art print-on-demand service which will partner with local artists, local businesses (including printer, shippers, and framers), and local art lovers who want to support their community by buying affordable local art.  This web-based service will host local artist’s work.  This does not have to be
limited to visual arts, but the visual arts will be our preliminary focus.  Our members will pay an annual fee, which will give the artist the ability to display their art work on the website.  Then, our representatives will reach out to local pubs, restaurants, retail stores, and coffee shops, requesting that they host our artist’s work in print form or digitally. 



 



 

What We Need & What You Get

 

Living in Columbus, Ohio, we have a very prominent cultural base.  The community is very supportive of their local artists; they are supportive of several local products PERIOD.  Since this is a key component for a business like Local Art Love © to work, I would like to use Columbus to be the main beta test market.  To start the business, I will need a budget of $10,000.  This figure will include covering the costs for the website design and maintenance, advertising, and promotions,


It will be the local business and artists who will partner, and also benefit from Local Art Love©.  Businesses who “host” our artwork will get a percentage of every print sold from their store.  Local printer and frame shops will benefit from our orders, and of course, local artists will have much more exposure and profits than they would otherwise.  There isn’t much of a downside for our partners.

 

The Impact

I believe that if given a choice, people like to buy products that are locally made.  In
Columbus, people are proud of the community they live in, and consciously supporting that community is an easy decision.  That being said, it’s easiest to support local businesses if the product is conveniently accessible to the local consumers.  That’s why independent bars and restaurants typically thrive, if they are offering a quality product.  Personally, I would rather support my favorite local restaurant over a TGI Friday’s any day of the week.  That’s why it only makes sense to pair an enjoyable night out at the neighborhood pub with looking at and purchasing vibrant local art to hang on ones walls at home or at work. 

Other Ways You Can Help

The best way for people to contribute to a cause like Local Art Love © is by consciously supporting local arts, retail stores, restaurants and bars.  Keeping money in the community is important, and to show support of local businesses and artisans will make sure our neighbors will thrive.

story:
The Idea.

This project is about answering questions. We are trying to start a small-scale pottery production and contribute to the Maine art scene, but the creative market is notably difficult. As young artists, we are looking to gain experience and better our understanding of the market. This project is about expanding our portfolios and skills while doing what we love. It is also about creating an image, a business, and most importantly, making a meaningful contribution to the greater art community.

We plan to create a variety of affordable pottery meant to be used everyday. There is no guidebook for young artists. We want to be transparent about this experience to share our successes (and failures) with other young artists by maintaining a blog throughout the process detailing and documenting our costs, strategies, and processes. 

We are not heading into the project blindly. We both have experience in the arts, and particularly in ceramics. 

What We Need.

In order to be able to maintain a selling model which is affordable, we need to reduce the start-up studio costs. We are borrowing and building much of the other equipment and materials needed for this project. 


Our major start -up expenses are as follow:

Kiln: $1000

Kiln instillation: $600

Raw materials: $200

Clay: 49 cents/lb. 


Our own studio ensures complete control over the firing process, allowing us to produce the work that we want to create. To use an existing community studio, we would be paying hourly-use fees upward of $15 each, in addition to firing fees. By having the opportunity to work in this way, not only will we learn more about what it takes to be working artists, but we will be able to advance our skills by having the ability to work longer and create more. 

The Impact.

Our project is intended to be about more than just funding equipment and selling our work. It does not end here. We will continually update a blog so that you can see what we're up to, and so that other aspiring artists can benefit from our project.

Please give as much or as you can. All funds will go directly to the purchase of studio equipment and supplies. We are creating sellable work, but by reducing our start-up costs, we will be able to make work that is affordable and accessible to all. Our work will be available in the greater Portland, ME area and online.

We want to make art, but more importantly, we want to learn while we do it. We are willing and eager to put ourselves out there, but we need your support. 

Finally, we ask that you support us by offering any suggestions, connections, ideas, impassioned warnings, questions, or advice that you may have. Thank you– we really and truly appreciate it. 

- m + e


Please follow our art-making adventure at: 

http://mepotteryproject.blogspot.com/ 

And on Facebook at:

https://www.facebook.com/mepotteryproject 


More About Us:

Maxwell Holden

Max with part of his Junior Review Exhibition, a collection of tea bowls. 

I am a senior at Hartwick College in NY, where I study Ceramics and Religion. I have been fully immersed in ceramics for almost four years, involving many classes, internships, and a semester in China. I have experience in the science of clays and glazes, technical kiln experience, and experience working for a community studio in ME.

See more: 

Facebook Page: https://www.facebook.com/maxwellholdenceramics

Blog: http://maxwellholden.blogspot.com/ 

Erin O'Leary

Erin with reject pots (which found a loving home with her sister). 

I am a sophomore at Bard College in NY, where I study Photography and Written Arts. I am mostly self-taught in ceramics, which I have been involved in for about four years. At Bard, I co-head the Ceramics Club, which launched in the Spring of 2014. I have work experience maintaining a community darkroom, as well as experience working for and making in a community studio in NY. 

See more: 

Portfolio:https://www.flickr.com/photos/erinfoleary

story:
Help us raise funds for our final MA show.

Why do we need funding? Putting on an innovative Digital Art show is expensive, the installations cost money and unlike say hanging a picture require sophisticated equipment and technology. Doing and MA is not easy and postgrads like us need a helping hand sometimes especially for our final show. All contributions of any amount is welcome and we truly appreciate your help.

Presenting a voyage into unknown digital possibilities with innovative Digital Art Installations at the University of Brighton, you can read more about our show below. Help us make this a fabulous show!

VOID - MA Digital Media Arts

Second Floor

58-87 Grand Parade

University of Brighton

Brighton BN2 0JY

Show: Saturday 5 July to Thursday 10 July 2014

Private view: Friday 4 July, 6pm to 9pm

Saturday 5 July, 10am to 5pm

Sunday 6 July, 10am to 4pm

Monday 7 July to Thursday 10 July, 10am to 5pm

The 2014 Digital Media Arts MA students present VOID - a voyage into unknown digital possibilities.

The show will run for one week and will be open to the public at the University of Brighton's Grand Parade campus. Dates and opening times are shown above.

VOID has been created by an international ensemble of postgraduate MA students each pursuing their individual specialisms and studio practice. The works presented ingeniously use a variety of digital technologies to explore a diverse range of creative themes and ideas. Prepare to be taken on a thought provoking, cultural, playful and cosmic journey through the minds of seven digital media artists, establishing themselves at the cutting edge of technology and artistic practice.

———

Lee-Ann Sandford is a graphic designer and educator from Canada who left the cold of her home country this year to seek new skills and gain a greater perspective within her work. Her driving ambition is to humanise technology and bring in elements of spirituality and enlightenment to the digital design process. Her work explores how technology can be used to enhance ones mind, body and spirit.

Lee-Ann’s final project is an exploration of the breath by creating an interactive journey through digital imagery. She will be creating an immersive experience that will enhance the awareness of ones own vital function by utilising elements of photography, sound and video.

———

David Evans Bailey is an artist engaging in the Hyperreal. He mixes metaphor with imagery to create an often surprising series of simulations. It is the ‘not’ real, the larger than real and the unreal that drives his work. His engagement is with the physical merging with the digital and beyond. His inspiration comes from the theories of Jean Baudrillard (1981). David’s post-modernist simulations make bold use of colour and saturation to create a contextual space in which is imposed his order, the order of the ‘simulacra’ and of hyperreality.

———

Pablo Alvarez Murillo - NARCISSUS.  Alone. He is finally alone with his fears and dreads. Only a mirror proves to be to him the one who is, whom it faces. Amid the thick darkness he stares at himself when suddenly the reflection of his skin, mouth and eyes begins to deform. And thinks he recognises all those terrifying images that crosses his face as a projector onto a cinema.

Now he realises; what seemed to be a mirror is simply another screen, similar to that of the computer of his office or to that of the telephone that he keeps in his coat.

———

Cindy Wang is a Digital Media Arts (MA) student. Her final project is called ‘Swing in the sky’. It is a physical interactive installation based on swing. Through the use of digital technology and computer code, the participant wanders back-and-forth through the clouds to the rhythm of their swing, whilst loosing themselves within atmospheric music.

———

Adelina, a girl from China(中國). Her final project presents a window on Chinese culture, in particular Hanzi (漢字), Chinese traditional Chinese characters used in the writing of Chinese and other Asian languages. Her work challenges you to imitate and engage in the Chinese characters practice (書法練習) to give an insight into traditional Chinese culture. The greater the similarity, the more you will be rewarded.

———

James Shreeve. The light that burns twice as bright burns half as long.

The replicant known as James Shreeve may appear to have all the hallmarks and traits of the standard human artist yet there is some spectacular programing behind those emerald green eyes. He has learned to assimilate and become a member of the artistic community even though it went against his beta programing. Some time ago his operating system was corrupted by a creative virus of patterns but now the pattern process permeates through his very existence. It could be said that the mind of James is hardwired to see through the trappings of world and gaze at the patterns which control the system

———

Jon Sayce is fascinated by the ingenuity of the natural world and draws much of his inspiration from the wonders of nature. With a background in design and graphics, his journey has been one of exploration into creative digital possibilities that blur edges between the natural and artificial.

———

How to get there: http://www.brighton.ac.uk/maps/grandparade/
