story:
OUR Story

Hello Everyone! GOT FRAMED is an exciting and playful art installation that debuted at Burning Man 2015 with phenomenal participant interaction! Imagine riding your bike and encountering a 12ft tall gold picture frame for people to dress up with their friends and play inside while someone captures the moment from outside. Swing and hang from the monkey bars across the top, climb up the side ladders and jump into the center! Snap a pic from outside and the moment lives as a souvenir forever. The highly interactive design promotes community participation, encouraging PEOPLE to BE THE ART. Inspired by the artist's Abuela ROSAmelia, whose 91 years have been spent living in the moment, Got Framed invites you to do the same! To say out loud, "I AM A MASTERPIECE!"

  • El NiNO's first magical Burn (2011)

El NiNO was born and raised in Puerto Rico. He joined an exchange program during his sophomore year and transferred to IPFW in IN where he finished his B.A. in Graphic Design, with a minor in Performing Arts. After graduation he then moved to LA. In the last 10 years, he's been working as a Production Designer and Art Director for events, stage, film and TV. Including NBC's reality show American Dream Builders, installing Pae White's "Woven Walk” at LAX International Airport. Manufacturing "Cactus" by Christian Moeller for the San Antonio Convention Center, TX. And most recently "Wild Art" at the LA Zoo for the non-profit organization RuckusRoots. He since had an awakening to switch his path and pursue his talents as an artist again. It started with painting a nursery mural as a gift to friends. After that, he created several other murals. El NiNO found himself feeling a different satisfaction for big canvases and enjoys the freedom to imagine on a bigger scale. In 2015, he designed and brought "Got Framed" to Black Rock City receiving Ty Eckley's award for one of the best and brightest art pieces at the event and lots of wonderful press. 

  • Ty Eckley's Award - Best & Brightest Art Pieces at BM 2015

For all of you who enjoyed GOT FRAMED in 2015, please share your picture with us. We created several ways to share your memories:

FB page: https://www.facebook.com/ArtInstallationGotFramed

Email: gotframed2015@gmail.com

Instagram: @got_framed and/or #gotframed

 

We Need YOUR HELP With TRANSPORTATION

We are honored to be invited back again to this year's Burning Man. Your funding will help us with a 16' truck rental, gas and millage. Truck rentals are very expensive and charge by each mile driven. A round trip to Gerlach, Nevada from Los Angeles is an estimate of 1100 miles. This is the exact reasoning for our campaign this year.

OUR PERKS

We have partnered up with some wonderfully talented artist creating great perks for your enjoyment and some unique Got Framed memorabilia.

Burner owned business: Boonzy Arts Candles: Soy candles, hand-poured in Los Angeles. Owner, Lauren Rock, is preparing a very special scent just for Got Framed's enthusiastic.  With your donation you will receive two (2) 4 oz. candles with magical "Playa Rose" scent. Mmmmmm.

  • Boonzy Arts Candles: "Playa Rose" scent 4oz

We also have our talented jeweler and fellow burner, Jessie Kavanaugh. Her gorgeous Kava Luna Handmade line will be creating a one of a kind jewelry piece just for YOU. A necklace with a small playa filled vial so your always close to home. Also for very generous donations a special Rose Quartz piece will be created just for you.

  • Rose Quartz pendants (stone design might vary depending on demand)

In addition, we would also like to share with our contributors one(1) hand painted wooden "Gold Rose" cut out. A very integrate part of Got Framed's design. Your very own Burning Man 2015 Got Framed's souvenir.

  • Got Framed's hand painted gold wooden rose

 

OUR Precious Impact: JOY

GOT FRAMED's first year on the playa was a humbling success, with hundreds of pictures of participants enjoying it and expressing there loving memories.

Check out our Instagram account: @got_framed 

After last year's success, it's been showcased in Huntington Beach & at the IgNight Fire Flow Conference in Joshua Tree. 

Your valuable support towards bringing GOT FRAMED back to Burning Man will help us with our goal to bring more smiles, joy, laughter and memorable experiences to the community we love so much. 

Any extra funds made from this years transportation campaign will be used to take care of meals and lodging for Our Fabulous Got Framed crew...

AND we are delighted to introduce our 

NEW ART PROJECT for BURNING MAN 2017

-MÚCARO- 

an art installation designed by El NiNO. 

Múcaro is a 21’ wooden owl with large, powerful telescopic eyes, a wise and wondrous appearance, and a head that turns 360! At night, the eyes become beams of light, strong enough to spot any art car in the distance.

The exterior will be made of wood; some new, but most will be reclaimed in overlapping pieces to create a “feather” look. Size is 12’w x 21'h; body height of 13.5’, head height of 7.5’. The interior will be made of strong, reinforced wood so participants can climb from the inside up to the top where you can then begin turning the owls head.

Please "like" our new FB page to updates about the incredible journey to Burning Man 2017. 

FB page: https://www.facebook.com/mucaroartinstallation

  • Múcaro's model

 

OUR 2016 Fabulous Crew

In 2015, we had a fabulous crew that made Got Framed possible. We are eternally grateful and they will certainly be missed. This year, we are going with a new fabulous crew eager and ready to build Got Framed again. 

  • Got Framed's Fabulous 2016 Crew

Artist/Project Lead: El NiNO 

Lead Builder: Evan Dillon

Project Manager: Sage Ward

Crew Coordinator: Nina Kawasaki

Camp Coordinator: Jessie Kavanaugh

Builders: Errol Navickas, Natalie Yallouz

 

Other Ways You Can Help

PLEASE SHARE our story. Also please let us know if you will like to stop by any of our build days and/or loading and unloading dates. We will be very happy to spend the day with as much laughter as possible. 

We are grateful!

GOT FRAMED's Fabulous 2016 Crew!

story:
THE STORY

Laundromat is about this man in search of his identity and the truth in his past. He seems to carry a load of unconscious guilt because in the dream, he sees himself buried in the sand by the kid. As we come to the end of the film, we come to realize where the guilt stems from. He probably hasn’t been the perfect dad or husband to the family he now remembers he had. Mike also seems to have a tendency to keep him from remembering the family. Perhaps he’s just trying to protect his brother or maybe he himself has something to do with that family.

ABOUT MARJAN HASHEMI

Marjan Hashemi was born and raised in Iran. She graduated in literature and then received her master’s degree in psychology. She then went on to study acting and played roles in Tv series and short films. In 2017, she received an award for directing a play at Hilaj Festival.She made her first film in 2017 and the film was nominated for best short film at WOW festival in Dubai. The Drip(2018) was her second film and had screenings in Iranian and international festivals including Kerala Film Festival. She made her third short film in 2019 and it competed in various festivals around the world including Paris, Germany, Canada and the US. She’s currently a student in advanced TV and film at Sheridan college mastering in writing and directing.

The Laundromat is her new project; a story about a man who has lost his memory in an accident and is struggling to connect to his past. little does he know that hurtful truths are awaiting him on this journey. Identity crisis is one of the most challenging issues in our modern world. How many times have we asked this question of ourselves: Who am I? This film deals with that question. The character experiences painful moments trying to find out who he really is and it’s very relatable because all of us go through these chaotic periods in our life trying to make sense of it all.

 

MY STORY

Being an immigrant, I have personally dealt with identity issues and I understand how hard it can become at times when one’s in the dark about aspects of oneself and the past.

I believe this film has a story to tell all of us. It encourages us to take the courage to explore within ourselves and not to be afraid to tread into the unknown part of us to realize who we really are.  

 

OUR TEAM 

 

MARJAN HASHEMI

https://vimeo.com/353306306

SIDDHI PATEL

Producer and editor, she loves films as they are the only medium that can make people empathize and feel something.

www.theorangebooth.com

CYRUS LO

Cyrus is a filmmaker passionate about stories that deal with humanity and the struggles of one person to find their own identity. Having been involved in productions of various sizes from short films to feature length movies, he can contribute his expertise to help the production finish on time and on budget.

HOUSSENI SYLLA

Producer and Sound editor, originally a design student from Humber College, he has produced multiple low budget short films in the past. “The Laundromat” is an ambitious project, and it will be the biggest film he’s worked on yet.

 

TIMELINE

June 13: pre- production

June 19: Finalize funding (Take this campaign live)

June 25: Script to be locked

July 1: Prep

July 19: production

July 25: Postproduction

 

WHAT WE NEED

We are film students of Advance Television & Film working on executing our final project name, The laundromat.  We are asking for support to raise the final capital required to make this film. 

We all have contributed some amount as a capital, but we need your contributions to reach our goal. Your contributions will help make this film as amazing as we know it can be!

The funds will go towards paying the set dec, food and location cost as well as post production and festival submissions. Your support will help me make it that much more impactful. 

 

PRODUCER CHALLENGES

To execute this film, we need funding for Production Design, Travel and Food. We wish to submit this film in festivals and market it across different countries. 

 

Stories on families are relatable to all, we want a larger audience to see this film and understand our message. We need funds to do so

WHAT WE NEED

 

We are film students of Advance Television & Film working on executing our final project name, The laundromat.  We are asking for support to raise the final capital required to make this film. 

We all have contributed some amount as a capital, but we need your contributions to reach our goal. Your contributions will help make this film as amazing as we know it can be!

The funds will go towards paying the set dec, food and location cost as well as post production and festival submissions. Your support will help me make it that much more impactful. 

Requesting the audience  to  get the word out and make some noise about this  campaign and share with the others. Your contribution will help us learn and make films.

story:
WHO IS WUSSY

WUSSY is an independent, Queer media company founded in 2015 out of Atlanta, GA. We created WUSSY because we wanted the autonomy to tell our own stories. Our Queer community is vast, colorful, vibrant, and a hell of a lot more fun than the traditional capital G gay mainstream media portrays us. 


What We DO

The core of our mission is to create spaces for Queer artists. We do that through -- 

  • Publishing a Bi-Annual print magazine, featuring a vast array of international Queer artists, movers, and shakers. We've self-published and self-distributed eight volumes so far.
  • Curating monthly events -- drag shows, film screenings, art exhibitions, comedy events, poetry readings, open mics and more!
  •  The WUSSY Podcast Network -- launched in the summer of 2020, we publish three weekly shows (Good Judy, WUSSY Movie Club, and Secure the Gag) 
  • Fostering community via social media -- we have garnered an active following on Instagram, Facebook and Twitter who look to us for updated news on Queer Art & Culture 
  • Lots and lots of memes
     


The Pandemic

When the lockdown started in March 2020, WUSSY had a whole years worth of fundraising events lined up from April - December. Without the fundraising from those events, we were unable to publish our planned Fall/Winter 2020 issue. 

We went full speed ahead into creating new avenues for our regular performers and contributors to make money and stay active. With the help of Southern Fried, Queer Pride, we raised nearly $20,000 in the form of micro-grants for Southern & Appalachian Queer artists and their projects.

Despite other promoters and clubs in Atlanta and across the country acting recklessly and still holding indoor events, we held firm and did what we could to create safer, outdoor events like the Drive-In Drag Shows and the O4W Artist Market. 

During the winter time, we've had to put those events on pause.


How You Can Help

WUSSY cannot exist without the support of our readers, patrons and loyal followers.

WUSSY vol.09 is scheduling to release mid-April, with an amazing lineup of featured artists including Ryan O'Connell, Bowen Yang, Cole Escola, and director Cheryl Dunye. 

We need to raise enough funding to cover printing and production costs like photography, writing, graphic design, etc. For one of our feature shoots, we even had to hire a rapid COVID-19 testing truck for the entire crew, which was quite expensive! >.<

Your donations will go towards making this print issue a reality and helping with a lot of our administrative costs on the backend. It is our hope that by the Fall of 2021, we will be able to start having more fundraising events again.

Help us get there, y'all!
 

What You Get!

You will be one of the first to receive a copy of our Spring/Summer print issue -- WUSSY vol.09!

In addition to preordering your print issue, you will receive some of our exclusive new merch items. 

WUSSY Original yellow 100% Cotton 3-Layer Fabric Face Mask!

WUSSY Never Fake It! Enamel Pin

WUSSY Embroidered Patches

Can't Donate?

We are all struggling right now! 

If you cannot afford to donate, please consider sharing this fundraiser, subscribing to our podcasts, and leaving us a 5 star review. Those kinds of things can go a long way!

story:
SEATTLE, WA – Being. is a collaborative split-bill production from Seattle dance artists Angelica DeLashmette, Kelsey Diane Hamon and Sarah M.F. Oxford that will premiere at Velocity Founders Theater April 1st-2nd 2016 in Seattle’s Capitol Hill neighborhood. Being. will debut two unique dance works examining ideas around human existence. DeLashmette will present her newest work that investigates the idea that we are eternal beings, without a beginning or an end. The idea that we did not come to be out of nothing, but always existed as intelligences; matter unorganized, which became organized into form. The work extends its inquiry to link time with timelessness, connecting our past with our present and future, and how the linear time we currently experience is a foreign time dimension. Composer, musician, and sound designer Madeleine Cocolas will be creating an original sound score for the work and dance media artist Bryon Carr will be creating and designing the visual technology. The work will feature five performers. Sarah M.F. Oxford and Kelsey Diane Hamon will perform and present their work in collaboration with installation artist Antonia Price. Their new work will explore what it is to be human, the different aspects of ourselves, how they interact with each other, and how those interactions affect and are played out in our interpersonal relationships with others.

PRODUCERS|CHOREOGRAPHERS|PERFORMERS: Angelica DeLashmette, Kelsey Diane Hamon, and Sarah M.F. Oxford

SOUND DESIGN: Madeleine Cocolas

DANCE MEDIA ARTIST: Bryon Carr

INSTALLATION ARTIST: Antonia Price 

PERFORMERS|COLLABORATORS: Abby Bradetich, Amber Homer, Elizabeth Sugawaraand Colleen Hoelscher 

HOW YOU CAN HELP

Consider making a donation to support Being.! Help us reach our goal!

MINIMUM GOAL to Produce Being.: $2,000.00

STRETCH GOAL to cover most production costs: $3,500.00


What Your Donations Will Go Towards: 

1. Theater Rental: $1,120.00 

2. Videography and Photography: $750.00

3. Publicity and Marketing: (Posters, Cards, Concert Programs) $200.00

4. Artist Fee: $1,000.00 ($100.00 for each collaborator) 

The artist fee helps artists with out of pocket costs for costumes, props, materials, and all other costs for creating their work. 

5. Rehearsal Rental Fees: $2,000.00 

OTHER WAYS YOU CAN HELP

If you can't support us through a donation, there are MANY ways YOU can make a difference! We appreciate every ounce of energy and support you can send our way! 

SHARE our Indiegogo Campaign on Social Media! 

LIKE us on Facebook!

INVITE friends to our EVENT!

PURCHASE tickets for Being. and come to the show! 

http://being.brownpapertickets.com

THANK YOU FOR YOUR SUPPORT & WE HOPE TO SEE YOU IN OUR AUDIENCE IN APRIL!!!

story:
UPDATE: Hours left! Campaign ends April 12th. Thanks to my current supporters for helping me get this far! The featured perk of $50 is the most popular, perks start from $5 on up. Any amount is greatly appreciated. My thesis show goes up April 20th to the 26th, opening on April 22nd at the Bard Photography Program: Woods Studio Exhibition Space. I have much to do in the coming weeks. Thank you so much for your support!!

  • My sculptural sound structure installation is done
  • Announcement postcards are going out (see it in the gallery images)
  • Framing now - cost over $2,000.  for 18 - 36 x 24 frames
  • Printing now (estimated cost $1,000)

I am getting clearer on the costs and how important this Indiegogo is for my project. In other words how important YOU are to helping me create this Personal Utopia Installation. See the Perks! & Please share this link on social media: https://igg.me/at/personalutopia/x/13327937

SUMMARY: My name is Jessica Chappe and I am a Photography Major at Bard College. This indiegogo will help me fulfill my senior thesis exhibition. My Senior Thesis Project is called Personal Utopias: passion projects that are creating a growing vision through collaboration.

KINGSTON MODEL TRAIN CLUB (photo credit Jessica Chappe)

I was raised in two communities that I consider my utopias. They have made me who I am today. They give me peace of mind and allow me to feel at home. Home, in the sense of physically feeling safe, comfortable, and alive—letting go of a façade and truly being authentic. Once I have graduated I would love to find my own passion project where I feel like I am making a difference; maybe not in the grand scale of things but through human connection and creativity. This is why I am on the look out for these personal utopias; because I want to learn what it takes to create a piece of my heart. This project is meant to celebrate what people can make through alternative visions. 

This project is aimed to find a spectrum of utopian environments and communities. So far I have photographed the:

  • Kingston Model Train Club
  • the Longspoon Collective (in Saugerties)
  • Bike Kill (in Brooklyn)
  • a meditation dome in the woods (in Pine Plains)
  • a family of campers (Ontario)
  • a 3-year-old’s fairy themed birthday party (in Hudson)
  • a medieval reenactment (in Kingston)
  • the Matt Bua’s B home (in Catskill)
  • Slab City, CA
  • Biosphere 2, Tuscon, AZ
  • Paolo Soleri's Arcosanti in AZ
  • Green Gulch Zen Center, Muir Beach, CA
  • Salvation Mountain, CA
  • Joshua Tree, CA
  • Camphill
  • Melody Africa
  • Oral History of Female Drummers
  • Earthdance
  • And more to come!

I am recording interviews, am creating a sound piece, as well as a sculptural piece.-a Geodesic Dome! The vision for this project is to make an experiential immersive gallery presentation for the viewer through exhibiting the variations within utopian communities and environments. 

What I Need to Finish My Project

Even though I have a good start on my project I need the ability to travel and be able to expand my project as much as possible, and then print and frame my images. I am still deciding on places to visit depending on funding. The detailed list needed for travel is below, including the expenses needed to finish the gallery show. 

REVISED Description & Breakdown of Expenses

    • Materials for sculptural element. $150
    • Zoom H4n 4-Channel Handy Recorder: I bought a used sound recorder to aid me in recording at each community I visit.  $150
    • Required: Create 2 Books for the Gallery Show using: http://www.blurb.com $75 x 2 = $150
    • Required: Paper and Ink costs and framing. (note changes in this budget item- doubled) My cost should be around $1000 for paper and ink costs, $450 for framing but may go over that.  The photography department will charge me for the cost of paper and ink used to complete this project. (some pay as much as $2000, I am careful in my use) .
    • Bread and Puppet in VT http://breadandpuppet.org/about-bread-and-puppet The name Bread & Puppet is derived from the puppet theater's practice of sharing its own fresh bread with the audience of each performance as a means of creating community, and from its central principle that art should be as basic to life as bread.  $50 for gas+ $0 (lodging with friends) = $50
    • Locations I plan to visit: Earthdance- MA, Oral History of Female Drummers-NYC, Folk Art Guild - NY, etc. $100
    • Expenses TOTAL   $2,265

& What You Get

See the PERKS for giving!

(Note: The images in the video above are not the final photographic images that will be in the gallery exhibition though the Kingston Model Train Club will be in the exhibit.)

Other Ways You Can Help

If you just can't contribute, that doesn't mean you can't help:

  • Please share my Personal Utopia project to get the word out using the Indiegogo share tools!

                                                                                                            Jessica  Chappe

story:
We are Hannah Rae Alton (London), Catrin Morgan (Nottingham), Amy Goodwin (Cornwall) Irene Vidal Cal (Galicia, Spain), and Anne Harild (Copenhagen).  We named our project Cassiopeia after a constellation in the Northern hemisphere composed of five stars. Cassiopeia is a project that aims to explore and foreground the importance of research and pursuing your interests, not just for artists but for everyone. As a group of collaborators our interests are in systems of knowledge, particularly those relating to communication and architectural structures.

Installation shot of Cassiopeia: Hand at Primary Studios, February 2016

Anne, Hannah and Catrin met whilst studying at the Royal College of Art where they discovered shared interests in architecture and cryptography. Anne and Hannah worked on a collaborative project in Berefet and Njawara, Gambia, where knowledge about traditional music and culture was shared and Hannah worked with some of the Gambian collaborators to make crystal radios, allowing them important access to national media. In 2013, Hannah and Catrin exhibited work looking at radio and code breaking at Bletchley Park. Amy and Irene met on an MA at Falmouth University where Catrin now teaches. They realised that they had a shared interest in cryptography when, after visiting one of Catrin’s shows, Amy and Irene began to email her in Morse Code.

We’ve been discussing work and research as a group since 2015 and had our first show together in February 2016. 

Irene and Catrin discussing work at Primary (Nottingham).

Cassiopeia is a project that will continue throughout 2016. In November we will have an exhibition at Guest Projects in Hackney and we are planning to document the year in a publication. Each part of the project is a development of and a response to the last one. We are applying for a grant from the Arts Council to help us fund our Guest Projects show and the publication. In February 2017 we hope to return to Primary to complete the project with a final exhibition.

Irene Vidal's practice communicates a particular view about popular culture, historic resonances and the poetics of politics. She works with revisions and appropriation of history in order to merge factual occurrences and fiction within her practice. Her work is currently examining the popular archive within the context of the Franco dictatorship in Spain. She has participated in programs such as Apprentice/Master Exhibitions at Kunstpodium T (Tilburg, The Netherlands) and is currently undertaking a collaborative residency at the Porthcurno Telegraph Museum as an artist and researcher in their archive. 

Decade Volcanoes, Irene Vidal Cal, 2014


Amy Goodwin’s practice uses the traditional craft of sign painting to explore the heritage and stories of the traveling fairground. She enjoys uncovering myths and dubious narratives, which are then documented through narrative layers in her sign-painting. In Autumn 2016 Amy will begin a practice-based PhD undertaking the construction of ‘an archive of illustrated space’: constructing more fixed and definite identities for the fairground-women. She has worked with Giffords Circus and Carters Steam Fair and runs ongoing workshops with archives and primary schools in Cornwall. She is currently undertaking a collaborative residency at the Porthcurno Telegraph Museum, responding to their archive material through research and practice. 

Installation shot of Amy's work at Cassiopeia:Hand at Primary studios in Nottingham, February 2016

Primarily drawing based, Hannah Rae Alton’s work also involves small-scale sculpture and film. Her main area of interest is the process of communication: how it is successful, when it breaks down. This focus has led her to make work about the physical function of radio, historical documents (Horror: Lightning In Serene Sky, 2011-12, commissioned by the Armitt Museum) and cryptography at Bletchley Park, (The Wondrous Tale of Alice and Bob, 2012, ArtHertz). Her research and drawing project, Dennis Wilson: Passage (2014) investigates the dissemination of historical information online and the internet archive in a loosely narrative format. Hannah has run workshops for Frieze, the Roald Dahl Museum, New Vic 6th form college, and MA Authorial Illustration at Falmouth University, as well as teaching regular life drawing classes in London.

Phoneme Drawings, Hannah Rae Alton, 2015

Anne Harild makes work that is based on research and investigations of the built environment, the systems and structures that support, shape and guide our daily lives. Anne works in a variety of medium e.g. collage, sculpture and stop-frame animation. Most recently Anne was ARMA artist in residence at The Bluecoat, Liverpool. She has exhibited in group shows in the UK and abroad among others as part of Atelier a Habiter at z.33 (Belgium), Paradigm Store at 5 Howick place (London) and Shadow Lines at Tintype gallery (London) as well as creating site specific images for Art on the Underground which are on display in various tube stations in London. Furthermore Anne has facilitated workshops and worked on collaborative projects with schools and community groups for among others Tate Britain, Camden Arts Centre and The Frieze Art Fair.

Folds, Anne Harild, 2011

Catrin Morgan’s practice explores the relationship between text and image with a particular interest in creating work governed by underlying frameworks, rules and hidden meanings. Most of her projects are conceived in relation with the book format, from limited edition artist books to mainstream publishing. Her research on theTaxonomy of Deception developed into a PhD at the Royal College of Art, a project closely connected with her illustrations for Ben Marcus' novel The Age of Wire and String, commissioned and published by Granta Books (2013). Catrin teaches at Norwich University of the Arts and Falmouth University and has facilitated workshops for the Royal College of Art and the Victoria and Albert Museum.

Studies for Studies #1, Catrin Morgan, 2016

The Cassiopeia: Hip show at APT Gallery in Deptford in May will be the second part of the Cassiopeia project. As a set of collaborators we not only share research interests but also particular research methodologies and the APT show will offer us our biggest opportunity to develop new ways of communicating these to the public through designing display systems, workshops and performances which will take place in the space. We did a test run of the project in February and the response was overwhelmingly positive: comments on the show suggested that showing our research alongside our practice offered visitors an unusual insight into the work – one which they really appreciated.

A crystal radio made during one of the workshops at Primary, February 2016

Being interested in what’s around you and looking further is something that can be valuable to everyone especially if you then go on to respond creatively to your findings. Our work explores the joy of uncovering something secret or the pleasure that can be found when you pay attention to things (such as scaffolding) that might appear banal or everyday. Research into cryptography highlights the strangeness and beauty of written language and studying buildings allows us to consider them as structures for organising people and information.

Support from you will help us to develop Cassiopeia into a beautiful and unique exhibition. We plan to build contemplative spaces or ‘studies’ within the gallery space at APT based on paintings of St Jerome in his study. These will offer us new ways of showing our work and articulating crossovers in our practice. Visitors to our February show commented that, "it’s wonderful to see research with the art, it gives a way into the work". Another visitor said that the show gave her, "access to information I've never seen before, I didn't even know of the existence of this research content. I would like to follow the progress of the research in further exhibitions". 

Amy at work


The more money we raise the more ambitious we can be in the display systems we build, workshops that we are able to offer and participants we can involve. For example, we would like to give local school children the opportunity of building crystal radios but will need to be able to supply specialist materials in order to make this happen.

We are looking to raise £3500 to cover costs of building display systems for the exhibition, a website, publicity, materials for producing the work and purchasing workshop materials. Any extra money we earn will be used to offer further workshops and to fund opportunities for post grad and under grad students to also offer workshops from within the APT gallery during the show.

Contributors will receive a variety of perks including:

·  Irene will send you a postcard with your own communication in Morse code 

Morse Code Postcard, Irene Vidal Cal

·  Hannah will send you a postcard with your own communication in Pigpen (a secret code dating from 1700s, used by the masons to record their minutes) 

·  Catrin will send a set of six hand painted colour block permutation postcards for you and five nominated friends 

·  Send us an object (more than 20cm on any axis and no more than 500g in weight) and Hannah will turn it into a crystal radio 

·  Amy will make you a hand painted sign showing the Cassiopeia constellation 

·  Amy will make you a hand painted sign with your initial 

·  Amy will make you a hand painted sign with a word of your choice 

·  Catrin will make you an original Maypole drawing 

Maypoles, Catrin Morgan, 2015

·  One of Catrin’s 'Studies for Studies' gouache paintings 

·  A hand drawn book made by Irene 

·  A print of one of Anne’s beautiful structures 


Images by Anne Harild installed at Primary, the left hand image is the original available as a perk, the right hand image has been made into a Gyclee print and is also available as a perk.

·  An original collage by Anne

Risks & Challenges

We made a test run for this exhibition and the workshops we plan to offer at Primary studios in February 2016. This gave us the opportunity to make detailed plans for the APT show and to anticipate any of the risks and challenges we may face in May. We’ve made slightly different plans for the APT show based on the different amounts of money that we are able to raise and as mentioned before, the more money we are able to raise the more ambitious we can make both the exhibition and the workshops we offer. We have the support of friends and family along with the guidance of Giovanna at dalla Rosa gallery who will help us to publicise and curate the show and Valerio at studio Julia who is advising us on exhibition design. We are working hard to make Cassiopeia as good as it can be.

We did a test run of the project in February and the response was overwhelmingly positive: comments on the show suggested that showing our research alongside our practice offered visitors an unusual insight into the work – one which they really appreciated.A crystal radio made during one of the workshops at Primary, February 2016
Being interested in what’s around you and looking further is something
that can be valuable to everyone especially if you then go on to respond
creatively to your findings. Our work explores the joy of uncovering something secret or the pleasure
that can be found when you pay attention to things (such as scaffolding) that
might appear banal or everyday. Research into cryptography highlights the
strangeness and beauty of written language and studying buildings allows us to
consider them as structures for organising people and information.
Support from you will help us to develop Cassiopeia into a beautiful and
unique exhibition. We plan to build contemplative spaces or ‘studies’ within
the gallery space at APT based on paintings of St Jerome in his study. These
will offer us new ways of showing our work and articulating crossovers in our
practice. Visitors to our February show commented that, "it’s wonderful to
see research with the art, it gives a way into the work". Another
visitor said that the show gave her, "access to information I've never
seen before, I didn't even know of the existence of this research content. I
would like to follow the progress of the research in further exhibitions". 


Amy at work
The more money we raise the more ambitious we can be in the display systems we build, workshops that we are able to offer and participants we can involve. For example, we would like to give local school children the opportunity of building crystal radios but will need to be able to supply specialist materials in order to make this happen.
We are looking to raise £3500 to cover costs of building display systems
for the exhibition, a website, publicity, materials for producing the work and
purchasing workshop materials. Any extra money we earn will be used to offer
further workshops and to fund opportunities for post grad and under grad
students to also offer workshops from within the APT gallery during the show.
Contributors will receive a variety of perks including:
·  Irene will send you a postcard with your
own communication in Morse code 


Morse Code Postcard, Irene Vidal Cal

· 
Hannah
will send you a postcard with your own communication in Pigpen (a secret code
dating from 1700s, used by the masons to record their minutes) 
· 
Catrin
will send a set of six hand painted colour block permutation postcards for you
and five nominated friends 
· 
Send
us an object (more than 20cm on any axis and no more than 500g in weight) and
Hannah will turn it into a crystal radio 
· 
Amy
will make you a hand painted sign showing the Cassiopeia constellation 



· 
Amy
will make you a hand painted sign with your initial 
· 
Amy
will make you a hand painted sign with a word of your choice 
·  Catrin will make you an
original Maypole drawing 


Maypoles, Catrin Morgan, 2015

·  One of Catrin’s 'Studies for Studies' gouache paintings 
·  A hand drawn book made by Irene 
·  A print of one of Anne’s beautiful structures 




Images by Anne Harild installed at Primary, the left hand image is the original available as a perk, the right hand image has been made into a Gyclee print and is also available as a perk.
· 
An original collage by Anne

Risks & Challenges
We made a test run for this exhibition and the workshops we plan to
offer at Primary studios in February 2016. This gave us the opportunity to make
detailed plans for the APT show and to anticipate any of the risks and
challenges we may face in May. We’ve made slightly different plans for the APT
show based on the different amounts of money that we are able to raise and as
mentioned before, the more money we are able to raise the more ambitious we can
make both the exhibition and the workshops we offer. We have the support of
friends and family along with the guidance of Giovanna at dalla Rosa gallery who
will help us to publicise and curate the show and Valerio at studio Julia who is advising
us on exhibition design. We are working hard to make Cassiopeia as good as it
can be.

story:
The New Independents is an emerging group of creatives, seeking to embolden and empower the role of art in the 21st Century. We...

  • Create a radical, open space for art to be made and discussed.
  • Engage with the myriad of new artistic communities and cultures.
  • Offer a platform through which art may be discovered.

And now we're publishing our inaugural magazine.

Just a few months into this journey, and we have the opportunity to make a publication filled with the writing and work of talented people from around the globe. We are incredibly proud to present the collected efforts of artists both new and established, including poetry from C.A. Conrad, Jack Collom, and T.C. Tolbert.

Please consider helping us pull together the funds to print this magazine and start on new projects--we've got a great list of rewards to sate any kind of artistic hunger, for both creators and consumers.

And of course, this is only the beginning for us. A portion of our campaign goal will be put towards establishing a budget for our upcoming events, publications, and productions. We've got a website in the reworks, a gang of great writers to begin reporting on our media, and whole bunch of projects involving our community, especially the New Indie Pack--check it out in the campaign rewards. More photos and information to come.


                                            

TNI is publishing its inaugural magazine and needs your help. As an emerging small press publisher, The New Independents aims to find exuberant new artists and create a space for their voices to emerge and be heard.

With our first publication we will be pairing some well-known writers with new and exciting voices. Though only a portion of the money raised by this campaign will go toward the publication of the magazine, the rest of the money will be used for future publications, distribution of magazines, and payment for the wonderful people who have supported us in this venture.

The New Independents aim to be a voice in the small press world for a good time to come. This small starting base will allow us to grow the group, reach a new audience, and continue to publish fresh and invigorating artists.


                                        

Because we want to do much more than just a magazine -- the New Indie Pack is a subscription box we're launching that will include a variety of works from independent artists within our community. For this first box, we've got Two E.P.'s, a Short Film, Art Prints, and a Poetry Chapbook -- all contained within a neat little package to arrive at your doorstep! 

                                         

                                               

A writer hailing from the Hudson Valley, New York, he is a graduate from the Jack Kerouac School of Disembodied Poetics. Currently Tyler lives in Boulder, Colorado where he serves as an instructor and creative director for the Boulder Writing Studio and tables at the local-famous restaurant. He has worked as a book reviewer for online blogs, a freelance journalist, and an editor.


                                       

                                              

A writer and literary enthusiast from the Hudson Valley, Colton is a recent graduate from the English Department at SUNY Oneonta, and has also studied at CUNY Hunter and the University of Oxford. He has since served in a variety of odd jobs--recently working in the publicity department of Random House Children's Division and selling wine with BIN 94 Wines. He dabbles in freelance journalism and loves to sit down for a good interview.


                                     

The most important members of our team are the community we have begun to amass. The number one priority is to support the youth artist around the country and globe in achieving their goals. Join our community on Facebook here.


                                    

To keep this short and sweet, here's a pie chart describing how funds will be allocated! Note that a large portion of funds will be put towards establishing a budget for The New Independents, which will thus allow us to produce future publications, events, and products based in our community.

story:
Summary

Intro:

'From Their Lips' will run April 20th - 26th at EnclaveLab in Deptford and will host a selection of events throughout the week. The works featured all engage with themes of sex work positivity from a variety of angles. We believe it is imperative to create an intersectional dialogue including the voices of queer sex workers, trans sex workers, sex workers of colour, and disabled sex workers, and to acknowledge the range of different lived experiences. The works span a variety of media, including video, sculpture, and photography in hopes of creating a more interactive experience for visitors.

Artists and Works:

Alli Logout - Lucid Noon, Sunset Blush

Lucid Noon, Sunset Blush follows the lives of a group of queer femme sex workers living together in a house in Texas and deals with overlapping themes of race, gender, feminism, sexuality, and sex work to present an honest and hopeful narrative.

Norene Leddy with Andrew Milmoe, Ed B. LePow, and Melissa Gira Grant- The Aphrodite Project: Platforms

The Aphrodite Project: Platforms has been described as a “social sculpture” designed as a conceptual homage to Aphrodite. It consists of platform shoes simultaneously designed as a practical device for sex workers and as a new media artwork to promote a public dialogue. The shoes contain a small screen that plays videos related to Aphrodite and can display advertising for the sex worker wearing them; they also feature an alarm, GPS, and a button to signal the police or sex workers’ rights groups, to promote safety for sex workers. The shoes have previously been shown as sculptural objects and used as part of various performances.

Vera Rodriguez & Nayra Green - Behind the Window

Behind the Window was created through the Sex Work Stories workshops, a series of workshops that teach sex workers skills in a variety of artistic media and display the results. The short film is based on a text written by Nayra Green about the day to day life of a sex worker that follows her thoughts while she is working, presenting a more human side to sex work.

Events:

Opening Night

The opening night will be held on April 20th. As well as getting a first look at the exhibition, there will be a performance by Christopher Bond and refreshments with donations going to Sex Worker Advocacy and Resistance Movement (SWARM).

Performance

Christopher Bond will be repeating his performance on April 24th at 5pm

Talk

Vera Rodriguez will be doing a talk via skype on Sunday, April 22nd.

Screenings

On Sunday, April 22nd, the film Sunflowers of Nicaragua  (Girasoles de Nicaragua) by Florence Jarguay will be screened at 3pm

 

What We Need & What You Get

What we need:

Although we have generously been given £1200 of funding by the Goldsmiths Alumni & Friends Fund, we need another £600 of extra funding to cover all of the costs of the exhibition, and ensure that the artists are paid fairly. An important part of the sex work conversation is ensuring fair pay for labor and we believe it is important to pay the artists a fair fee for their contributions. Here is a basic breakdown of all of our costs so you can see exactly what your donation will be supporting:

Artists' Fees (£150 each x 4 artists) £600

Installation Materials:

Plinth for Aphrodite Project: Platforms (plus shipping) £85

Red velvet curtains for the windows £40

Neon sign £65

Hanging equipment £5

Transportation of works:

Shipping from US to UK and back again of 'Platforms' £400

Other works £100

AV Equipment rental for a week:

TV with trolley stand £60

Headphones (£5 each x 2) £10

Projector £45

Marketing: Leaflet Printing £50

Private view refreshments £100

15% Contingency £240

Total: £1800

What you get:

£5 - Thank you & credits on exhibition information

£10 -  Artist postcard along with thank you & credits on exhibition information

£20 - A4 artist print along with thank you & credits on exhibition information

£50 - A3 artist print along with thank you & credits on exhibition information

£100 - A private talk with the curators along with thank you & credits on exhibition information

 

About the Curators

Kezia Davies is a curator based between London and Liverpool, currently studying for an MFA in Curating at Goldsmiths. She is working on ideas of re-framing feminism as a curatorial lens through which to view artworks and exhibitions, rather than as a singular theme.

Samantha Moreno is a curator based in London. Originally from Texas, she is completing her MFA in curating at Goldsmiths, University of London. Samantha is interested in how the curatorial can be used to amplify diverse, unique voices with an emphasis on migrant, feminist, and Latinx perspectives.

story:
My Story

Friends & Family-

I want to say a huge THANK YOU ALL SO MUCH for donating, for supporting me and taking the time to read about my struggles and help me on my journey to fulfill my dreams. This past week I received an email that informed me my trip to New York City is cancelled due to Miki Agrawal, the author of the book Do Cool Shit, having too much going on to give her time to the bootcamp. I am incredibly disappointed and have been trying to figure out the best way to tell all of you. I’m frustrated I was put in this position at all, but I understand the busy lives of entrepreneurs. 

That being said- I want to give you all the option of receiving a refund or helping me form a new game plan, a new boot camp if you will. Please, if you need the money back for whatever reason do not hesitate, I will not be offended. After some time grieving this trip being cancelled I decided if the opportunity won’t happen in New York City I will make it happen here in this awesome startup hub St. Louis.

The main goals of my trip to New York City were too:

1. Clarify my brand, nail down exactly what services my business will offer

2. Network with others to form a community of like minded people

3. File for an LLC

4. Develop a professional website

5. Run and grow a business I can take with me as I travel around the world as a pastor’s wife. And a lover of travel in general

How can I do this here in St. Louis?

1. Meet with Brevity, or a similar service, which will help me with digital design and branding to clarify my brand and reach my audience with a clear, concise message. Funds I raised from the Do Cool Shit trip will go towards using this service.

2. I am working with a friend to get a spot at a startup incubator, which means I will use funds raised from this trip to pay rent for my space. I am going to tour TechArtista Saturday to check it out and get the total cost for the year (until I leave with Nathan for vicarage).  Funds from the DCS trip will also go towards this space.

3. With help from the incubator since many of them have an LLC, plus my soon to be brother in law is a lawyer, I hope to successfully file for an LLC within a year.

4. With the help of Brevity or a similar service I will develop a crystal clear, modern website that delivers the message of my brand to my consumer

5. I plan to make my business digital to start, so that I can take it with me as a travel the next few years. Anyone that has a pastor in their family can tell you it’s not an easy life, and women struggle to establish themselves while they constantly move. I want to be someone who can take their business on the go, as well as a resource for women struggling to follow their passions as they are taken from one place to the next.

My online presence will begin as a platform for my creative services, but after I settle into a city I plan to develop a brick and mortar that will look something like this:

If you haven’t, look up an 826 store and imagine the front of the studio made up of tangible art, written word, and design created by struggling artists, closet poets, and defeated 9-5ers sketching intricate designs on their notepads while they wait for the next tedious task. At the back of the studio I want to build a community for people who don’t have people to turn to in order to talk about their creative projects. People who don’t have encouragement and have no clue how to even begin to pursue their dreams. I want to build a place for people to explore creativity, establish deep connections, and overall create a supportive environment that encourages creators on their path to success. We all have it in us, but I know it has taken a community of people to get me to the place where I am now. I want to give that gift to others.

I am working on getting exact prices for TechArtista and Brevity and will shop around other services for the best deal. Any suggestions, or if you want to call me to talk about ideas, whether your own creative endeavors or ideas on how I can build and clarify my brand please email me at susanvbecher@gmail.com, give me a call/text at 314-650-1432, or meet me for lunch/coffee. There’s a cute barista at Kaldi I like to hit on in Clayton so I’m always down to go there and chat!

Again, I will NOT be offended if you decide you want a refund. I am not trying to hold your money captive, I am trying to allocate it in a way that still supports me starting my own business. Here’s how you get it -> https://support.indiegogo.com/hc/en-us/articles/526876-Refunds

Love you all!

What I've Been Working Toward & How This Camp Will Help

I began my fashion design major because I originally wanted to start my own business selling my own fashion designs, but my idea has evolved greatly since then. I took many art, design and creativity classes in college and worked for a local entrepreneur named Lily Dawson to help her run her own business. Since graduation I have worked with two other entrepreneurs, one CEO of Algorythmics and the owner of Belli Fiori, along with wedding planner Brittani Joyce with floral design. I love the startup community and have been learning all I can from these amazing women on how to start, run, manage and keep a startup relevant and successful. I have also read stacks of books focused on following passion, quitting day jobs, starting my own business, and of course Miki Agrawal’s Do Cool Shit. I still continue to design and make art along side my multiple jobs working with startups and kiddos at a local public school. I have learned how difficult it is to start a career after college, especially a creative one, and want my business to support those held back by fear and insecurity. 

These funds will be allocated towards a startup space in St. Louis along with a service that will help me clarify my brand and present it to others. I will be able to build relationships, get the answers I need, and fully put myself out there to start my own business.

Why Your Investment Matters

Your money will help me learn as much as I can to get my business starting while connecting me to awesome people. Your money will hold me accountable for starting my own business, which will only push me further to begin my startup. Your money will help me start a business that helps people find purpose through community, while giving artists and aspiring entrepreneurs a place to sell and start their own business. 
You will help me become an an example to others, that we can overcome insecurity, anxiety, depression or whatever fears are holding us back and together we can become a community of DOERS.

Where Your Money is Going

- Towards my space at TechArtista (price to be determined this weekend)

- For a Brevity, a digital design and branding website (TBD as soon as possible, I'm getting on it)

Other Ways You Can Help

If you can't contribute cash, that's totally okay! You can help me by:
  • Spread the word to family, friends or people who love to support peoples dreams!! 
  • Use the Indiegogo share tools!

Any suggestions, or if you want to call me to talk about ideas, whether your own creative endeavors or ideas on how I can build and clarify my brand please email me at susanvbecher@gmail.com, give me a call/text at 314-650-1432, or meet me for lunch/coffee. There’s a cute barista at Kaldi I like to hit on in Clayton so I’m always down to go there and chat!
Again, I will NOT be offended if you decide you want a refund. I am not trying to hold your money captive, I am trying to allocate it in a way that still supports me starting my own business. Here’s how you get it -> https://support.indiegogo.com/hc/en-us/articles/526876-Refunds
Love you all!
What I've Been Working Toward & How This Camp Will Help

 

I began my fashion design major
because I originally wanted to start my own business selling my own fashion designs, but my idea has evolved greatly since then. I took many art, design and
creativity classes in college and worked for a local entrepreneur named Lily
Dawson to help her run her own business. Since graduation I have worked with
two other entrepreneurs, one CEO of Algorythmics and the owner of Belli Fiori,
along with wedding planner Brittani Joyce with floral design. I love the startup
community and have been learning all I can from these amazing women on how to
start, run, manage and keep a startup relevant and successful. I have also read
stacks of books focused on following passion, quitting day jobs, starting my
own business, and of course Miki Agrawal’s Do Cool Shit. I still continue to
design and make art along side my multiple jobs working with startups and
kiddos at a local public school. I have learned how difficult it is to start a career after college, especially a creative one, and want my business to support those held back by fear and insecurity. 
These funds will be allocated towards a startup space in St. Louis along with a service that will help me clarify my brand and present it to others. I will be able to build relationships, get the answers I need, and fully put myself out there to start my own business.
   Why Your Investment Matters
Your money will help me learn as much as I can to get my business starting while connecting me to awesome people. Your money will hold me accountable for starting my own business, which will only push me further to begin my startup. Your money will help me start a business that helps people find purpose through community, while giving artists and aspiring entrepreneurs a place to sell and start their own business. 
You will help me become an an example to others, that we can overcome insecurity, anxiety, depression or whatever fears are holding us back and together we can become a community of DOERS.
Where Your Money is Going


- Towards my space at TechArtista (price to be determined this weekend)
- For a Brevity, a digital design and branding website (TBD as soon as possible, I'm getting on it)
  Other Ways You Can Help
If you can't contribute cash, that's totally okay! You can help me by:

Spread the word to family, friends or people who love to support peoples dreams!!  Use the Indiegogo share tools!

story:
Short Summary

Armine, Sister is a multipronged project that includes creation of a performance and presenting it in Poland and abroad, work on publications, among others on a photographic album, organising photographic exhibitions, panel discussions and concerts of musicians. The project is the first manifestation of the new domain of the group’s work –WITNESS/ACTION. ZAR collaborates with the Gomitas Institute, the Armenian Embassy in Poland and Armenian associations.

Join us on Facebook: www.facebook.com/ArmineSister
Read the story of Armine: http://armine-sister.tumblr.com/
Visit our webpage: www.teatrzar.art.pl


"Armine, Sister". Teatr ZAR, phot. Karol Jarek.

  • Awarded performance "Armine, Sister" refers to the history of the Armenian people in Anatolia and their near-extermination at the beginning of the 20th century. The project enters into the history of Europe’s silence and is a refl­ection on the act and inheritance of witnessing.

  • The project has been realised in both artistic and research fields, which include expeditions, studies of Armenian history and music tradition and work sessions led in the Grotowski Institute in Wroclaw. In the years 2010-2012 the company travelled to Istanbul and to Anatolian cities, Yerevan, and also Jerusalem, and met with choir leaders, chorists, and musicians, some of whom take part in the work on the performance work. Among them is Istanbul-born Aram Kerovpyan, master-singer of the Armenian Cathedral of Paris, who has become the key collaborator in the research. The project focuses on the phenomenon of the Armenian monodic singing tradition and the way it has been preserved or not in diaspora which was largely formed after the First World War as a result of the Armenian Genocide in 1915.

  • Rather than focusing on the history of the events of 1915 or the history of the ensuing denial and taboo, Teatr ZAR centres on the history of ignorance that feeds on inaction and leads to inaction on the part of today’s Europeans. On the other hand, the history of ignorance also includes the social story of building an accord of silence around each act of violence. The events in Anatolia in the early 20th century launch us into a wider debate about lessons in “witnessing after witnessing”, which always turn into lessons in identity.

  • Armine, Sister not only reveals the history of the Armenian extermination, but also the history of silence and the responsibility for it. ­The work explores what it means to be a witness, and what witnessing means to us today. We cannot and do not want to speak on behalf of Armenians, but we wish our performance to break the chord of silence.

    WITNESSME instalation in  Oslo, 4-6th of March, phot. Magdalena Mądra.


Why you should support us?

Our goal is to recall memory of Armenian Genocide. To do it we have to show as many people as possible the story of Armine.

  • Art is the best way to keep memory alive. Don't allow to bury this tragedy in sand. We believe in a deep sense of theatre as a vehicle of memory.

  • We worked on "Armine, Sister" for several years. This spectacle was awarded several times, but most importantly it has always awaken emotions. 

  • The spectacle is ready to go, the actors are wonderful, you just have to see it for yourself.

Jaroslaw Fret, phot. Magdalena Mądra


Article about our director

"Fret unearthed these collaborators—who come, pointedly, from societies representing both the aggressors and the victims in the conflict the play depicts—over the course of recent research expeditions to Istanbul, Yerevan, Jerusalem and thereabouts, and has melded their spare, haunting, rarely heard monodic singing techniques with ZAR’s own flawless polyphonic singing"

Here you can read a full article from American Theatre in pdf version: http://bit.ly/1bANvF8


What We Need?

We need money for:

  • Presenting the world an issue of neglecting memory of Armenian Genocide.
  • Visiting with our spectacle additional cities around the world.
  • Preparing exhibitions, paying actors.

Additionaly we need money for: 

  • Spreading the word about the project in international media. 
  • Spreading the word about Armenian Genocide in regular and social media.
  • Preparing a historical exhibition commemorating Armenian Genocide ( something like http://www.kennedyandoswald.com/of course the final look depends on a gathered amount of money)
After the project will be finalised we will present a detailed calculation of all expenses in our crowdfunding campaign.

Old pictures and stories, phot. Valeria Cocco.


Unique Perks

Wall of thanks

It's very important for us to put your name on our wall of contributors. Your donation makes everything possible. We are very grateful for your support. Your name will be visible on our site among other contributors.

Limited edition photos

These photos, made by a great photographer Magdalena Mądra, are both beautiful and compelling. There are two categories of photos — from a spectacle and from our expeditions to Anatolia. You can see there deserted ruins, and history burried under the sand.

St. Theotokos Church in Tadem, phot. Magdalena Mądra

Photos with autographs

Printed version of limited edition photos with autographs of our actors. Great thing for every collector.

Music tracks

Music tracks from our spectacle. The music is very unique. You can hear some of it in our trailer. We will put here a lot more info about this perk.

CD with music from spectacle

Full soundtrack with compelling chants from our spectacle "Armine, Sister".

Invitation to a spectacle

The best chance to see us at work. You won't forget this experience. In touring section we will write down all venues, where you can see our show. With your support this list will grow bigger every month.

Meeting with actors

A unique chance to speak with our international cast of actors about their work and to talk with a director about making an art a vehicle of memory. For sure you will get inspired. 

Singing workshops

Amazing workshops lead by greatest Armenian traditional musicians and our cast. One weekend full of work. Unique technique of singing and acting. A visit in a heart of the world greatest theater laboratory.
Number of places strictly limited.
We will write a lot more about this experience.

Sponsors

For our sponsors we prepared three special offers. You can choose between regular, gold and diamond status. You logotype will be placed in special sections on our pages and our leaflets and posters. If you need every further details, please write to us.

For every question concerning perks or anything else we are more than happy to answer.

Aleksandra Kotecka and Simona Sala in "Armine, Sister", phot. Irena Lipińska


Touring

APRIL 2015
WROCŁAW

"Witnessing After the Witnessing" exhibition
Venue: Instytut Grotowskiego
13-30.04

Traces exhibition
Venue: Instytut Grotowskiego
21–27.04

Witness
Venue: Instytut Grotowskiego
22-27.04

Armine, Sister
Venue: Instytut Grotowskiego, na Grobli
25-27.04

SINGING IN EXILE/CHŒURS EN EXIL/ Premiere of the film
Venue: Instytut Grotowskiego
28.04

WARSAW
Columns. Armenian liturgical chants
Venue: TBA
23.04

MAY 2015

FLORENCE
FABBRICA EUROPA 2015

“Armine, Sister” performances / Teatr ZAR
Venue: Stazione Leopolda, Viale Fratelli Rosselli 5, 50144
8–10.05

A pomegranate is a recurring symbol in "Armine, Sister", phot. Valeria Cocco.

SAN FRANCISCO
SAN FRANCISCO INTERNATIONAL ARTS FESTIVAL 2015

“Armine, Sister” performances
Venue: Herbst Pavilion, Fort Mason Center/ 2 Marina Boulevard (Buchanan Street)
24–26, 28.05

“Armine, Sister” performances
Venue: Herbst Pavilion, Fort Mason Center/ 2 Marina Boulevard (Buchanan Street)
29–30.05

Concert “Twinklings of Hope”presented by Mahsa and Marjan Vahdat with accompaniment of Khyam Allmi or Shervin Mohajer
Venue: The Chapel, Fort Mason Center/ 2 Marina Boulevard (Buchanan Street)
23.05

Concert. "Columns. Armenian liturgical chants."presented by Teatr ZAR with Aram, Virginia and Vahan Kerovpyan, and Murat İçlinalça
Venue: TBA (to be announced)
27.05

Workshops led by Teatr ZAR’s members
Venue: TBA (to be announced)
25–27.05

JUNE 2015
ROME

"Armine, Sister" performances
Venue: Teatro India
20, 21, 22.06

“Witness” Action

Venue: Pincio, Villa Borghese
17-21.06

Concert "Columns. Armenian liturgical chants."
Venue: Basilica Santa Sabina
18.06

JULY 2015
SZCZECIN

OCTOBER 2015
BERLIN
PARIS

NOVEMBER 2015
MADRID
WARSAW

DECEMBER 2015
LOS ANGELES

JANUARY 2016
NEW YORK

FEBRUARY 2016
DIYARBAKIR/STAMBUL

FURTHER DATES AND DETAILS WILL BE ANNOUNCED

"Armine,Sister", phot. Karol Jarek

Risks & Challenges

Teatr Zar is a professional group with an international team of actors. Our work is well known around the world. Our spectacles were presented in USA, England, Scotland, Romania, Norway, Poland, Spain, Greece, France, Spain, Italy, South Korea, India and most recently during Theatrical Olympics in Pekin.

  • The main issue is the negation of Armenian Genocide by several countries around the world. Till this day Turkey hasn't recognised these tragic events. There is no political will to change this situation. To overcome this issue we want to speak directly to people, their feelings and conscience.
  • The main theme of campaign to recall memories of Armine and all lost lives and stories isn't the most attractive topic for mass media and public opinion. That's why we are going to use social media and indiegogo for our cause. The direct response of people, sharing and all mechanisms of Facebook, Instagram, blogs and crowdfunding are the best way to get a recognition of Armenian Genocide.
  • Our spectacle is an experience hard to forget, our exhibitions and instalations are beautiful and compelling. We sing long lost songs, we bring to life stories. Emotions, direct contact, closeness and music are the best way to suceed in this theme.

Other Ways You Can Help

Support us. If you can’t  donate your money please share this info with your friends. Follow Armine on Facebook. Help her to recall her name. Donate your voice, donate your face. Be a witness.

story:
Show some love for community arts ♥

River Region Arts promotes local arts events:

  • RRA seeks to bridge the gap between various arts organizations in our community by offering a comprehensive arts calendar, news, reviews and more through our website and social media outlets.
  • Sponsorships make our work possible.
  • In addition to information about arts events, RRA offers class listings, Hunter's History of Pop and many other editorial features.

Local praises for RRA

Area leaders highly value River Region Arts:

  • Kristy Meanor, Executive Director
    Wetumka Depot Players, Inc.

"From day one, I have been impressed with the comprehensive coverage River Region Arts provides.  As the executive director (and only staff member) for the Wetumpka Depot Players, I often find that I am so absorbed in our projects that I am not aware of what else is going on in the other River Region theatre, music, dance, etc communities.  I learn about a new event, project, restaurant or artist every time I visit the either the website or Facebook page.  Being in the know makes me a better leader for our organization!"

  • Lara Lewis, Director of Public Relations and Marketing
    Montgomery Museum of Fine Arts

“River Region Arts is a resource for supporting and promoting the arts in the River Region. Its dynamic leaders, Mark and Rhonda are extremely energetic and passionate about the arts in our region and do a wonderful job of reaching out to EVERYONE who is connected to the arts community. They promote all arts organizations, big and small, and we are so grateful. As most know, arts organizations are small-staffed and operate on very small budgets, any amount of promotions are valuable, but especially the quality ones from River Region Arts.”

  • Greg Thornton, Artistic Director
    The Cloverdale Playhouse

 "The banner that runs across the River Region Arts web page (which is wonderful, by the way) reads 'Create, Explore, Inspire.' I cannot think of three other words that better define what we do.Whether it is in music, film, theatre, or the visual arts, all of us spend our lives in pursuit of all of these verbs. With Rhonda and Mark heading this terrific new group and chronicling what goes on around the Region, we have a great resource that will alert us to new and exciting projects and remind us all of why we do what we do. River Region Arts shall truly encourage us participate fully in the arts, whether as artist, audience, or supporter."

  • Emily D. Flowers, Managing Director
    The Cloverdale Playhouse

"Long overdue in an area with a thriving arts scene, River Region Arts.com brings a unified approach to shopping the arts. One calendar, one website, one stop to see what's going on in Montgomery and the surrounding area. River Region Arts is tremendously valuable to Montgomery's artists and audiences.
RRA has helped the Cloverdale Playhouse spread the word about auditions, upcoming performances, volunteering, and the Playhouse School. We love what riverregionarts.com brings to the river region!"

Thanks for your support! If you are proud of the arts in your community, show some love and sponsor RRA. We can't do it without you.

story:
I am a South African artist based in Johannesburg. I've secured a gallery space for my first solo exhibition; but need to fund a percentage of the costs myself.

My show is titled “Precious territory” which is a reference to childhood, the importance of play in a child’s development, and a loss of innocence in the face of pervasive mass media. It is largely inspired by my experiences of fatherhood since the birth of my son, Campbell, just over a year ago. I have started to truly appreciate the value of childish innocence.

By helping me reach my target you will be helping me take another step towards my lifelong dream of being a career artist. I currently work in the advertising industry, notorious for long hours and heavy overtime requirements, and I am watching my son grow from a distance.  I want to be more active in his development and working from my studio at home would allow this.

You can view my past work and exhibitions at www.andrewsprawson.co.za 

 

What do I need?

$3 500 once converted it to South African Rands will covers the costs of framing, printing catalogues, placing adverts in arts publications, and if I am frugal, it could even provide some refreshments at the show.

It will make ALL THE DIFFERENCE!

 

What do you get?

By contributing you will stand to receive a range of perks. I will be giving away a range of original artworks, the size of which depends on the size of the contribution. Basically, send me an image of your dearest toy from childhood and I will render it lovingly in watercolour and inks. Just for you.

Here is a breakdown:

$150- A4 (11.7 x 8.3 inches) artwork (unframed)

$300- A3 (16.5 x 11.7 inches) artwork (unframed)

$500- A2 (23.4 x 16.5 inches) artwork (unframed)

$1000- A1 (33.1 x 23.4 inches) artwork (unframed)

 

Other ways to help?

If you haven’t the cash-flow to help me make this dream real by contributing money, you could help me out by sharing this campaign with your friends, family, colleagues… literally anyone you know who has an interest in the arts.

The further the word spreads the more likely I am to pull this show off in a way that will WOW the critics and buyers!

Indiegogo has user friendly sharing tools to make this as easy as possible.
story_txt:
I am a South African artist based in Johannesburg. I've secured a gallery space for my first solo exhibition; but need to fund a percentage of the costs myself.
My show is titled “Precious territory” which is a reference to childhood, the importance of play in a child’s development, and a loss of innocence in the face of pervasive mass media. It is largely inspired by my experiences of fatherhood since the birth of my son, Campbell, just over a year ago. I have started to truly appreciate the value of childish innocence.
By helping me reach my target you will be helping me take another step towards my lifelong dream of being a career artist. I currently work in the advertising industry, notorious for long hours and heavy overtime requirements, and I am watching my son grow from a distance.  I want to be more active in his development and working from my studio at home would allow this.
You can view my past work and exhibitions at www.andrewsprawson.co.za 
 
What do I need?
$3 500 once converted it to South African Rands will covers the costs of framing, printing catalogues, placing adverts in arts publications, and if I am frugal, it could even provide some refreshments at the show.
It will make ALL THE DIFFERENCE!
 
What do you get?
By contributing you will stand to receive a range of perks. I will be giving away a range of original artworks, the size of which depends on the size of the contribution. Basically, send me an image of your dearest toy from childhood and I will render it lovingly in watercolour and inks. Just for you.
Here is a breakdown:
$150- A4 (11.7 x 8.3 inches) artwork (unframed)
$300- A3 (16.5 x 11.7 inches) artwork (unframed)
$500- A2 (23.4 x 16.5 inches) artwork (unframed)
$1000- A1 (33.1 x 23.4 inches) artwork (unframed)
 
Other ways to help?
If you haven’t the cash-flow to help me make this dream real by contributing money, you could help me out by sharing this campaign with your friends, family, colleagues… literally anyone you know who has an interest in the arts.
The further the word spreads the more likely I am to pull this show off in a way that will WOW the critics and buyers!
Indiegogo has user friendly sharing tools to make this as easy as possible.

story:
Short Summary 


We believe the best things in life are not actually things, - but moments and experiences. This is your chance to be part of something really cool.  An Indiegogo campaign for bringing back a friend, come on ;)


We are raising funds to bring home our good friend Marc Bargalló. He has been studying abroad (in Barcelona) for the last couple of years, and has not come since. We want to raise some cash to pay for his ticket and welcome party. It is going to be awesome and you are all invited :)

What We Need 

We want to pay for Marc's plane ticket. Nothing more.

What You Get 

We will produce a documentary of his visit to Guatemala, which include: 

- everyday experiences in his nothing-but-ordinary life
- exclusive non-censored footage going to the bathroom and stuff
- and much more!

Other Ways You Can Help 

Share our campaign!
